item.title: Songs of Love and War: Afghan Women’s Poetry
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is a review of Sayed Majrouh's "Songs of Love and War: Afghan Women’s Poetry" .

The oral literature of Pashtun women practiced and handed down through generations are works composed entirely without awareness of the recognized western canon of literature, or any literary authority, and therefore remain blissfully uncorrupted by outside influences and devoid of any academic or technical preoccupation or prowess. Nonetheless, these short verses known as ‘landay’ remain comfortably at ease within their own simple structure using straight forward language and configuration. Without school or university education, the Pashtun women conjured and composed these verses as a release mechanism from the oppressive confines of their culture, which they understood as one that required their absolute obedience and silence within a male-dominated society.  Out of the repressive state of veiled hushed existence comes a response of torrential exuberance through witty, profound, tragic and sometimes cruel two-line verse composed of nine and thirteen syllables respectively. Through gut-wrenching rawness and breath-taking honesty, these poems/songs procure universal recognition, exude appeal and are understood forthwith. To be offered a glimpse into the inner sanctum of the mind of these anonymous Pashtun women poets is a rarity and a privilege, and in this compilation of ‘Songs of Love and War: Afghan Women’s Poetry,’ we are offered that opportunity. The collection of ‘landay’ verses were gathered and compiled by the visionary Afghan poet and academic Sayed Bahodine Majrouh, who was tragically assassinated by Islamic extremists on February 11th 1988 at his home in Peshawar.

The clannish tribal formation of the Pashtun society, operated traditionally entirely by men and male values like most other patriarchal societies, with the code of honour as fundamental law, appears to impose a harsh environment for women to endure. In the first chapter, Majrouh explains that in Pashtun society, love is taboo. Young people cannot see, love, or choose each other, but are articles of exchange where marriage partners are decided by clan authorities. Occasionally, a woman’s intended husband is either a child or an old man. If a girl is unfortunate enough to fall in love with someone other than the clan’s choice, it is regarded as a grave mistake sometimes punishable by death.[1]

Her only means of airing her sense of injustice, defiance and rebellion is through her composed verse, where she states:

Cruel people, who see how an old man leads me to his bed, And you ask why I weep and tear out my hair! Oh my God! Once again you send me the dark night. And once again I tremble from head to toe, for I must get into the bed I hate.

Equally on the prohibited subject of illicit love, the Pashtun woman expresses her passions with awe inspiring frankness in verses such as:

My mouth is yours, devour it and be not afraid. It is not made of sugar that might be dissolved. My lover wants me to kiss him in the foliage of the blackberry bush, and I leap from branch to branch to offer him my mouth. Come and kiss me without thinking of the danger. What does it matter if they kill you! True men always die for the love of a beautiful woman. Give me your hand, my love, and let us go into the fields, So we can love each other or fall together beneath the blows of knives.

On the subject of the tribal male code of honour, known as Pashtunwali, Majrouh writes: ‘in listening to them (landays) we can hear a huge burst of laughter, cutting, pitiless and without affection’[2]It is almost as if she were saying: ‘I’ll participate in your game and I’m going to make you shoulder the extreme consequences of your own principles’.[3]

If the male code of honour requires and insists upon female obedience and silent acceptance, then in times of war and battle, the Pashtun woman cunningly reverses the situation in her own favour with bellowing disdain and cunning silent manoeuvres. It is she who will decide how he should behave according to his own honour code.[4] If a man, including her own sons, returns home beaten in battle or humiliated due to some dispute, he will  inevitably be the recipient of scorn, sarcasm and supercilious ridicule  by the Pashtun woman and indeed by all the village women. It is she who advises him to behave like a hero in war and battle. For instance, if he returns and his injuries are on his back and not on his chest, his life will not be worth living as expressed in the following landays:

In battle today my lover turned his back to the enemy. I am ashamed of having kissed him last night. My beloved! If you turn your back upon the enemy, do not come home again! Go and seek refuge in a distant land. Go first, my love, to avenge the martyrs’ blood, before deserving the refuge of my breasts. If you do not have a wound in the centre of your chest, I shall remain indifferent, even if your back is riddled like a sieve with holes.

After the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, and due to the horrific slaughter, terror and destruction that ensued, the Landays take on a more tragic, heart-wrenching expression, particularly in their themes of exile, loss and love of the home country:

My beloved, my sun, rise above the horizon and obliterate my nights of exile. The darkness of solitude cloaks me from all sides. Living in this land of exile is ravaging my heart. May God let me return to the foot of my tall mountains!

Through themes of love, battle, death, honour, defiance and patriotism it is the strength of character, endurance of spirit and an innate fight for survival that reverberates and resonates through the landay, which are composed strictly by the Pashtun woman. Sayd Bahodine Majrouh has bestowed a great gift to the world. Within this work of beauty and purity, he has given a voice to thousands of anonymous Pashtun women and allowed us a glimpse into the very heart of Pashtun women, who constantly defy any claims that they are indeed silent, powerless submitters of the restraints of their culture.

[1]Sayd, Bahodine Majrouh, ‘Songs of Love and War: Afghan Women’s Poetry’, Other Press:N.Y., 2003, p.2

[2] Ibid., p.12

[3] Ibid., p12

[4] Ibid., p.14

item.title: A Gender Agenda
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
March 8th 2013 marked International Women’s Day: the globally recognized and celebrated socialist movement, with over 1,314 events staged worldwide. Observed since the early 1900’s when in 1908, 15,000 women marched through New York City demanding better pay, shorter hours and voting rights. Since then, improvements in favour of women’s equality and status have come to fruition, in many sectors and on many levels. Nevertheless, there are still critical territories in need of modification such as, equality of pay to that of male counterparts.  In today’s modern world, the recognition of women in their capacity as role model, in the workplace, and indeed all walks of life has increased dramatically. However, throughout various indigenous cultures of the world, we still find women whose lives remain dominated by age old traditions, customs and staunch patriarchal authority, as is the case for many Pashtun women. Particular aspects of cultural and social tradition, practiced primarily and predominantly in Pashtun society can often administer adverse effects in the lives of Pashtun women. It is important to state that not all Pashtun women are heavily influenced or burdened by the nature of their culture, and therefore cannot be categorized in general, or realised in terms of being uneducated or repressed.  Indeed, many Pashtun women have attained high political office in recent years, while others have successfully carved out careers in journalism and in many other areas of the social domain and workplace. Yet, a significant number of Pashtun women living in rural parts, such as the Federally Administered Tribal Areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Afghanistan, are affected in many ways by the traditional practice of the ‘code of honour’ known as Pashtunwali. This code of honour is an inherent, ingrained understanding among Pashtun society, where the tribal laws, traditions, rules and customs are adhered to and exercised, often with force, thus affecting and controlling many women’s lives in a negative way.  With a population of over 50 million, the Pashtun people are Afghanistan’s largest ethnic community and Pakistan’s second. Separated by the geographical border known as the Durand line (1893), the Pashtun community is a tribal, clannish formed society, traditionally operated entirely by men and male values, as seen in most patriarchal societies, with the regulated Pashtunwali at the nucleus of its culture. One of the most oppressive aspects of Pashtunwali is the responsibility of each individual to uphold the honour of the family and tribe. If honour is endangered on any level, the considered perpetrator may become an outcast or disowned by the entire family and clan. The fear of bringing ‘sharam’ or shame on the family weighs heavily on the shoulders of Pashtun women.   In Pashtun society, if a woman suffers injustice such as domestic violence, forced marriage, chooses a husband other than the choice of the tribe, confronts a husband over infidelity, acts or speaks in a way that is considered too liberal she will have to bear the consequences of her actions and words, with hostile and harsh repercussions from her immediate family and tribal members. For instance, a Pashtun woman who commits adultery can face the disconcerting prospect of being stoned in public by relatives or the entire clan, and in some cases she can face the grim prospect of death. As a result of the terror of inciting shame on the family, women are often forced to bear injustice silently, to live in fear, to deny and sacrifice their basic human rights in order to retain the honour and status quo of their immediate family and community. These factors certainly facilitate violent acts such as rape to go unreported and thus promote silent subjugation on the part of many Pashtun women.[1](In light of recent revelations concerning the treatment of girls and children at the Magdalene laundries here in Ireland, the concept of bringing shame to the family is not alien to our own collective consciousness. In the majority of cases, it was the close relatives of these young girls who decided their fate and therefore wittingly participated in sentencing them to a life of seclusion, misery and horrific abuse). Another widely practiced institution of Pashtun culture is the system known as ‘Jirga’, where a judging panel of honoured elders called ‘Masharan’ along with other influential men of the community, assemble  in order to settle  disputes and domestic problems that arise within the tribe or immediate locality. The Jirga practice, existed in Pashtun culture long before the advent of Islam, and upon its arrival, Islamic teaching through the Qur’an and Sunnah were incorporated into the Jirga system.  The long established and firmly fixed patriarchal system of Pashtun culture decides that the men of the community control the Jirga forum. There was a case recently in Afghanistan, where a woman spent six months trying to get a divorce through her local court. Eventually the case was handed over to the local Jirga council for a decision. Although the woman herself was not allowed to attend the hearing, her husband, the man she wanted to divorce, was a member of the panel. In the FATA areas of Pakistan and Afghanistan, many disputes are dealt with by the Jirga including the fate of many women. The lives of Pashtun women vary from those living in urban areas to those residing in rural areas such as the tribal belt. In Afghanistan after many decades of war and the subsequent rise of the Taliban, considerable hardship and curtailment of basic human rights have become the norm for many Pashtun women. The threat of aggressive and violent behaviour is enormous in certain areas of rural Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Afghanistan. These actions are sometimes driven by an inaccurate interpretation of Islamic law, as recently witnessed in the shooting of 15 year old school girl Malala Yousafzai by the Taliban. There are still many discriminatory practices affecting women across the modern world today. But as history shows us, change takes time, particularly in societies where long standing traditions and belief systems are deeply entrenched in the collective psyche. However, events such as International Women’s Day, allows the opportunity to share experiences, promote dialogue and to encourage a deeper understanding of the lives of less fortunate and often overlooked women across the world.

[1]  Malali Bashir, ‘The Cost of being a real Pashtun Woman’, www.pashtunwomenvp.com

item.title: Pashtun Boy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
She dreamed of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa

and how the burnt orange gravel

would feel beneath her pampered western feet

parched red earth, longing, grieving

its  liquid soul mate

 far, so far, never to consummate

forced resignation

 

Which colour would register upon his sober olive eyelids

submerged, dry, inflamed smoked blanket

hot burnt umber, golden orange, red,

carried through the Khyber in its storm weaving sync

eyes that never fathomed or memorized blue ocean

 far, so far, never to consummate

forced resignation

 

Then from the hard country came the harbinger;

crier of the impossibility of  dreams

Pathan loyalty, ingrained customs core

marching their way to cold Hibernia

teasing, mischievous, alluring, illusive distance

 far, so far, never to consummate

 forced resignation

 

A wave of silence louder than  majestic regal storm

carrying discontent abundant in its wake

 how could cupid consider to dream?

 challenging conjuring  a most unlikely union

 East , West, stubborn, solid, unimaginable

 far, so far, never to consummate

forced resignation

 

The heart is not akin to geography, custom or belief

no confines, words, history or mind's disease

can influence its invisible fluidic seeps

swelling, foaming, soaking, enveloping origins

 upon hot grounds where stands his eastern calloused feet

 spirits  wander undetected, Hibernian voices call;

Khyber, Nowshera, Peshawar, Mardan.

- - -

This poem was also translated into Pashto by Zakir Hussain.

Haghay yaw khob da pukhtoonkhwa ooleedo

pa khob ke weeni che da Pukhtunkhwa daa sawi lawi khawra pa khpal dozakh dozakh wajood

da haghay da day naazako narmo khpo da bloso

sa yakh ihsaas akhlee

dagha lathaaray khaawray khpal nazaka sawailai da ghumm pa runz akhta kree

da laray laray na raaghaly

Da haagha stergo da banro loogo wahali sawi lawi loopatay shaaloona

che jall wahali dee aw maraawi mraawi dee

pa khpala laman

da lwar khyber da toofaani sundaro kum yaw rung la zay werkawi

da pukhtun stergo khu yadoona humm da yakh samander obaailalo

da Pukhtano patt aw wafa che da khpal dood aw dastoor

humm dagha patt dagha wafa sho yaw astaazay da ghumm

dagha da ghumm astaazay raaghay da yakhbasta Hibernia pa sakhto sakhto laaro

pa kugglaichano zra raakhkunko laaro

raagahay khabar ye raawro

daa da khybera ter Hibernia daase zra staray mazal

pa dagha khob ke khaapairai sunga khoboona waeenee

da nmar khateez aw qablaizo khalqo

meinz ke faaslay wrakay kree

da laray laray na raaghaly da judaayaye jabbr pa zaan na mani

zra che qaghan da gughrafiya na many

dood aw dastoor aw aqeeday na mani

hess yaw maraz da tareekh na qablawi

daasi maraz da zra da weenay raftaar na shee neeway

daa masala da pa taatobo da bal shawo orrono May 20

che da Khyber da Pukhtoon klukay aw kaijay pkhay dee

khu ghugg ye haagha Hiberny awwaz de

Hibernia chaghay wahi ghugg werkawi; chughay wahi

Khyber Nawkhar aw Paikhawar yadawi

ghugg pa Mardan kawi....

item.title: A week in Islamabad
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When the prospect of my imminent solo visit to Pakistan was announced to family and friends I was confronted by a barrage of bewildered, fearful, confused, facial expressions accompanied by unceasing interrogation and a general suspicion by all that I had either lost my mind completely or maybe in need of some form of psychiatric help. Nonetheless, once I finally received endorsement from my university supervisor and blessings from one senior family member, all others were forced to retract into submission and allow me to silently leave Ireland and meet the horrible fate they envisaged awaited me in Islamabad. The first hurdle was crossed. I then had to apply for a visa through the Pakistan Embassy in Dublin. Similar expressions of disbelief and suspicion were muttered down the phone lines as the Embassy staff member conveyed to me that this would not be an easy application and would not be as simple as applying for a ‘holiday visa for Spain’:

Having listened to my reasoning and the announcement that I held in my possession, a letter from my university endorsing this trip, the official went on to regale the litany of documentation I would require to gain entry into Pakistan, such as:

 A letter from the head of a family in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, who would be responsible for my safety 24 hours a day; Proof of where I would be residing at all times; Proof of where exactly in the Country I was planning to visit along with various other necessary documentation.

Because my area of research and study is based around Pashtun culture, I proposed a visit to Peshawar and surrounding areas. The official then told me that this visa could take up to six months to acquire as this area of Pakistan was unsafe for me, even with letters and proof of security by an approved family. It was becoming apparent to me that I was facing an uphill battle trying to gain entry into Khyber Pakhtunkhwa as a single Western female at this time. I therefore decided that Islamabad, the capital, would suffice for my first visit to Pakistan, as I am lucky to have many Pashtun friends residing there and others from the Peshawar and Mardan areas made it clear to me that they would be prepared to travel from KPK to Islamabad to meet with me there.

On May 30th, I arrived in Islamabad International airport at 2.30am. Coming through the arrivals gate the first sight that greeted me was the presence of possibly around 200 Pakistani males awaiting friends and relations all of whom stopped suddenly in their tracks and began to stare at me as if I had just arrived from planet Venus!. Delighted with this unexpected deluge of attention from the opposite sex, I smiled broadly in acknowledgement of their inquisitiveness and interest. They proceeded to divide and make a pathway for me to pass, allowing me access to my awaiting complimentary taxi from my hotel. Arriving from Ireland where top May temperatures usually reach eight degrees at best, the heat felt ‘oven hot’. I didn’t care. I felt warm at last and for this one week, four layers of winter clothing would, thankfully, not be necessary.

I was lucky to have the agreement of my trusted and good Pashtun male friend to be my security guard for the week, and he dutifully accompanied me at all times; to and from places; advising and arranging many meetings with other Pashtun people, from whom I subsequently learned a great deal about their culture and day to day lives. Coming to an Islamic Country for the first time as a Western woman, I discovered quickly, that there were many issues of protocol to be adhered to and a specific mode of conduct required as a female.  Western customs, freedom of speech and behaviour to some degree would have to be curtailed. For instance, our usual custom of hugging and kissing friends on meeting in public places was frowned upon, and my bodyguard pointed out gently and in private that shaking hands was my best option.  But these minor readjustments did not hinder my enjoyment in the least and in fact, I welcomed the prospect of trying to blend in with the locals in as many ways as I possibly could.

A day of Pashtun music, song and poetry was arranged for me by the wonderful Pashtun poet: Akbar Sial. To my astonishment he invited my three good friends and I to Lunch, in the hills at Monal, overlooking the beautiful city of Islamabad. On arrival, we were introduced to Pashtun scholars, academics, musicians and a host of other polite and honourable Pashtun men.  I had heard about the famous ‘Melmestia’, or Pashtun hospitality, but this display exceeded all my expectations and I was made feel welcome and treated as one of their own kind. I found all the Pashtun men to be very polite, respectful, good- natured and happy that an Irish woman was so keen on learning about their vast and rich culture. The following hours were spent in warm sunshine, in the beautiful natural surrounding hills, listening to live Pashtun music, poetry and song.  Akbar Sial presented me with books for my studies along with copies of his own books and poetry works. One of the musicians played the ‘rabab’, which is the iconic instrument of Pakhtoons. Although I wasn’t able to visit Khyber Pakhtunkhwa on this occasion, this experience was almost surreal to me, as if part of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa had been brought to Islamabad especially for me.

[caption id="attachment_162" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Angel Merisi with poet Akbar Sial and Pashtun academics at Monal, Islamabad[/caption]

Two days into my trip it was becoming apparent to me and my bodyguard that I was attracting an exaggerated amount of attention in the streets mostly from the male population. We both reasoned that it was due to my western clothing. The mutual decision was then made that I would wear Islamic clothing with hijab for the rest of my visit. Completely covered except for my face and hands, this manoeuvre curbed the problem slightly but didn’t solve it outright and for the entire week I was still stared at whenever I ventured anywhere. I found it quite comical and asked different male friends as to why I still seemed to be attracting so much attention. My bodyguard said they were astonished and looking in disbelief because a western woman was walking through the streets, using local taxis and generally behaving unafraid and with confidence. Another male friend said that because I walked and stood with my head up and spoke directly with people that this was the reason for the excessive staring. Whatever the reasons were, I grew accustomed to it and it became of lesser importance as each day passed.

A trip to the National Gallery of Islamabad was a worthwhile venture. The collection houses many great works of art, in particular some magnificent works by Sadequain. To my surprise, the collection also contains many works of art depicting images of Buddha, the ‘Pieta’ and other identifiable non Islamic religious iconic images. A large room with sculpture made from twigs and branches depicting a mother and child framed a large wall. Across the room, life size figures made from plastic bags produced an inspired work of art, and in my opinion this room of installation was on a par with any of the contemporary art galleries I have visited across Europe. Excellent works and thought provoking. While the staff allowed me to take a couple of photos of some works, photography in general was frowned upon.

A visit to the Faisal Masjid has been one of my dreams for a long time and my bodyguard arranged for us to go there along with a group of his Pashtun friends. The Faisal Masjid is truly a beautiful and awe-inspiring place to visit, and there is a wonderful sense of peace in the surroundings of the building. Vast and monumental, with marble stone surface, surrounded by the Margalla hills, it was an unforgettable experience. Strangely, during our visit there, an electrical storm erupted suddenly, and for half an hour we were subject to a taste of Irish weather. At the small shop next to the Masjid, I bought a miniscule copy of the Qur’an which I will treasure as a reminder of this wonderful evening.

Many more trips to beautiful parks, the Pakistan monument, short hiking treks and other excursions were undertaken throughout the week but I want to discuss my thoughts and observations as a Western woman on my first trip to Pakistan. It is said that Pakistani mangoes are the best in the world and I, for one, am in total agreement. Every day without fail my bodyguard and I stopped at the same fruit juice shop for a pure mango juice drink. Every night we ventured to different restaurants, either Pakistani or Afghan. I’m a firm believer of always trying local cuisine and I must say every restaurant we went to the food was excellent. I would particularly recommend ‘Habibi’ restaurant. The food was good, the live rabab music was great and the seating arrangements were wonderful with large sofas draped with colourful materials, nice lighting and quite homely. I must also mention the Afghan green tea that I had on many occasions, which was really delicious and impossible to get as good a quality here in Ireland. Other great restaurants we visited were ‘Café la Montana’, Kabli, Lok Virsa, Lasania and a take out from Des Pardes. All offered excellent food and great service. Islamabad doesn’t have a central shopping district as such, but has many small areas with clusters of shops grouped together. The layout of the city is vast and divided into different sections and one has to drive or get a taxi to get from place to place.

 Finally I cannot end this article without a word about the traffic and drivers on the roads of Islamabad. The concept of ‘lanes’ or any type of road rules seemed to be non-existent. Cars and motorbikes swerved freely from one side of the road to the other as if they were the only people using the road. Overuse of the car horn will echo in my ears for a long time. Drivers were constantly beeping at each other, yelling at each other, yet nobody was taking any notice, just driving on regardless. The fact that there are not hundreds of road accidents in that City every day is a source of wonder to me. Security check points are of major significance in this city. I have never come across anything like this during previous travels. We were frequently stopped and asked for documentation, and often if the police got a glimpse of me, even in local taxis, my bodyguard had to get out of the car and explain what I was doing in the country and where I was from. They all seemed to be amazed that a western woman was in the country, and seemed suspicious of my motives. Indeed on my final taxi trip to the airport we were stopped on three occasions. By the time of the third checkpoint stop I was actually getting worried that I would miss my flight home. On this occasion a police man began asking me questions in English about my studies. He then proceeded to give me a short history of Pakistan and tried to tell me there is much more to the country than just Pashtun culture (He was Punjabi).  While I would have liked to have chatted with him for longer, in the end I almost begged him to please let me go and catch my flight!

I would definitely recommend a trip to Islamabad.  I found the people polite, friendly and helpful. I was never frightened at any moment during my stay and I can honestly say it was one of the best trips I have ever undertaken in my life. My only regret is that one week was much too short. I am already in the process of organizing my next trip which will be spent mostly in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, and it will definitely be a longer stay next time.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am totally agreed with you Angelina Merisi..... Pakistan is a Country that people must visit... a place that you will keep forever in your heart; and I am not surprised about the reaction of people at home telling us that we were out of our mind, people just share what media said.... but I also experienced some issues at the Pakistan Embassy.... going back and forward to get a month visa with some restrictions visiting some cities.... remember going the first time to apply in company of one of my friends and sitting in waiting room to be call and watching some videos of old news of 2010 about Kashmir, and suddenly my friend stand up and said.... I am sorry, but I think that you are totally insane trying to go there, and can be supporting you in this crazy decision.... lolzzzz..... I said.... well I am crazy , and I am going.... at the end she said to my other friends that I got the Visa because of my persistence.... Pakistan Embassy should promote the beautiful places that Pakistan has instead of those videos. We have enough with the media of that. Hospitality is one of the most attributes that Pakistani people have.... I was treated as a Queen.... and I am not exaggerating.... going to places like Bank or Official offices and waiting in line sitting instead of standing as all males were, or letting me go in front of the line, and not because I was a foreign, but cause I was a woman..... gave me the assurance that women are treated with a lot of respect..... well I just want to let people know that Pakistan is not only a Country to visit.... It is a place to keep in your heart..... I love Pakistan.... <3

if u need any kind of help or guidence please feel free to contact me. thanks n regards.

I figured out how to write a comment under this. Yay! Thanks for writing this, Angel! I enjoyed it, as everyone else did, too. Just want to share some thoughts:
Thank you for taking the time to write about your experience there! Every Westerner I know who's ever visited Pakistan, including Peshawar, has loved it--except for the being-stared-at-by-men. Yes, unfortunately, this is a common problem in many Muslim countries. It's terrible in Morocco here, too, but my worst experience has been in Pakistan (I'm from Swat, as you know) where they'll stare at you no matter WHAT you wear--western clothing or not. Also, just a few thoughts I want to share--and I wish I could post them under your post. How do I do that?
- "Western" clothing is not necessary any less or more "Islamic"; what you meant, I believe, was to say "traditional Pakistani clothing" as opposed to necessarily "Islamic" clothing. As a student of Islamic Studies, you get my point, no? There's a problem with suggesting that what you were wearing originally ("western" clothing--e.g., pants and shirt) were not "Islamic."
- As a Western woman, you're going to get a LOT of proposals from Pakistani men for marriage. I'm sure you're smarter than to think that they are sincere in their intentions, but just to remind you: our men (and our entire society, actually) is obsessed with white women and white people in general; we think they're more beautiful than us, just because of their skin color and hair color. We even try to be white but fail at being so because it's just against our nature because we're darker than "white" people. But besides this, the problem is that our men/people claim to love their land and will fight to death for it, but as soon as they see an opportunity that'll get them out of their miseries in their land, they grab it. They think Western women, including Pashtun women raised in the West who have citizenship in western countries, are an excellent opportunity for them to come to the West; and they know that marriage is a great way to make that happen. Of course, as a confused people, we love Westerners for the opportunities they come along with, we hate them for their apparent decadence, so we don't see them as marriage material. And so, our men generally who marry western women also almost always marry a girl from back home who's going to be, needless to say, "more traditional" than a western woman.
More later :) Thanks again for writing.

item.title: Taliban’s Office Drama in Qatar
item.dc:creator: ajmal-stanikzai
item.content:encoded:
In one part of the gulf-state, Qatar, there is the embassy of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, while in the other part there is the office of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan or the Taliban. Both represent Afghanistan, yet both have different interests. Such things can only happen to a country like Afghanistan where masses are uneducated, strictly religious and easily deceived.

Taliban is a terrorist organization that has committed countless crimes against innocent Afghan civilians throughout the past decade. Allowing them to open an office in Qatar gives this extremist organization and their crimes against humanity an international legitimacy and attention that they don’t deserve. They will use their new international office to find new allies and more sources of funding to continue their atrocities against the innocent Afghan civilians. America’s opening of an office for the Taliban in Qatar not only undermines one of its core principles, which is never to negotiate with the terrorists, but also weakens the Afghan government’s stance and hurts its credibility both at home and abroad. Establishing an office for the Taliban outside Afghanistan might mean that the Afghan government is not the sole entity representing the people of Afghanistan.

Let’s face it, Taliban are important because they have ruthlessly been killing afghan civilians. They got that office only because they have murdered numerous Afghans not because they are a strong political force. Knowing that they will be treated better, the Taliban will continue to spill more innocent blood and will stick to their illegitimate tactics simply because they work. Whether the Afghan government negotiates with the Taliban or a third party does, it will not be as productive as one might hope. It will only strengthen Taliban’s imaginary independence from Pakistan in some people’s eyes which is also a good PR for the Taliban. However, Taliban are not independent of Pakistani influence.

Opening an office for the Taliban in Qatar will not free them from the chains of Islamabad nor will it give Taliban the authority to make decisions on their own without the approval of the Pakistani military establishment. The key to peace in Afghanistan is with Pakistan. The government of Afghanistan should be talking to Pakistan about solving the Afghan problem. The US government too instead of raising Taliban to the status of an important faction of this war, without whom peace is unattainable, should pressure Pakistan to remove Taliban from its territory and to stop aiding and supporting them.

As long as the root cause of the problem which is Pakistan’s support of the terrorists in that region is ignored, such futile steps as giving Taliban an office in Qatar, will only divert attention from Pakistan and will waste the precious time in this critical hour. Pakistan is training more and more fighters to wage Jihad against Afghan and Western forces in Afghanistan while we waste time on a wild goose chase.

item.title: Western Media: You are poisoning the minds of our children
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday, I gave a lecture on Pashtun culture and of my wonderful and joyful experience in Pakistan to the staff, teachers, Principal and pupils from a local school here in Cork City in Ireland. I had prepared my lecture in advance which comprised of a discussion surrounding the History of Pakistan, The Durand line, Pashtun culture, (including poetry, music, Pakhtoonwali) and the religion of Islam.

Before my lecture began, I asked the children if they knew anything about Pakistan or Afghanistan. Many children raised their hands. The following answers were given to me: ‘Terrorists’, ‘Suicide bombings’, ‘Taliban’, ‘Dangerous people’, ‘They hate Western people’. While I hadn’t planned to discuss political issues, of which I know very little about, I felt such horror that these children ranging from eleven to thirteen years of age had consumed such a one-sided and negative view of these Countries and their people. Therefore, before my lecture began, I decided to invite a discussion concerning Western media and its strong influence on the minds and subsequent decision making of our children.

#While it is necessary for the media to give an account of the horrific atrocities occurring repeatedly throughout these regions, I pointed out to the children that these terrorists, whom have been responsible for much death, carnage and sorrow, are a very small minority and that most Pashtun people, Pakistani and Afghans despise these acts of violence. I explained to the children that the majority of people from these regions are peace-loving, thoughtful, respectful and caring. I felt saddened by the fact that children of such a young age were being ‘fed’ this torrential onslaught of negativity and are rarely given the opportunity to discover the other side of the story.

I am not stating that media coverage of dreadful killing of lives should be hidden from the public domain yet I feel it is as much a crime not to portray the positive and wonderful aspects of other cultures in equal measure. Surely if East/West relations are to improve, it is more deserving and necessary for our children to be offered a more rounded and comprehensive understanding of these cultures.

If our Western children are being poisoned from an early age by media sources, then how can we hope for a greater understanding and acceptance of the people of Eastern cultures in the future? After my lecture, I told the children that I hope they will visit these regions some day and make up their own minds and draw their own conclusions, without the often misguided and one sided portrayal by Western media.

item.title: Poetry of resistance
item.dc:creator: shinwari
item.content:encoded:
The beginning of this year witnessed the launch of some new Pashto poetry books, versifying the present social turmoil and militancy. Poets and writers are among the most vigilant and responsive souls and sensitive to any kind of change in the social fabric. It is not surprising then that over the last few decades Pashtun poets have profusely written on different forms of terrorism that have wrecked havoc on people’s lives and caused a huge damage to their social, political and cultural set up.

 Poets have focused on the causes of the ‘war on terror’, leaving thousands of innocent people dead, numerous injured and millions homeless. There is a withdrawal from the conventional way of expression; it’s more the poetry of the mind than of the heart. It condemns more than it resists militancy and the militant’s way of ‘reforming’ the Pashtun society.

 Pashto poets have not only bemoaned the shaking foundations of their cultural institutions at the hands of the militants but have also bravely raised their voices against the militants’ anti-Pashtun vision.

 Right from Khushhal Khan Khattak and Rahman Baba to the Khudai Khidmatgaar Tehreek of Baacha Khan, Pashtun poets and writers have always offered strong resistance against tyranny, oppression and extremism and upheld their social norms and traditional values for peaceful co-existence with other nations. Pashtuns are liberal, large-hearted and democratic people keeping a balance between the hujra and the jumaat — the social and religious obligations.

 Ali Akbar Sial, a senior Pashto poet and author of many books, hailing from Malakand Agency, is the most vocal among contemporary poets. As early as in the year 2000 he had brought out a collection of poems titled Pa Jung De Or Olagee (To Hell With War) followed by another titled, Daa Paharoonah Ba Gundal Ghawaree (These Wounds Need To Be Healed).

 Ukhkay Ukhkay Musketub (The Tearful Smile) came out in 2005 and in 2009 he published Zamung Pah Kalee Ke Shar Mah Jurrawai (Don’t Create Chaos In Our Village). The most recent one, Pah Guldaru De Warawal Orronah (Raining Bombs On Floral Valleys) garnered widespread fame in Pashto literary circles for its unique and bold style.

 The force behind Pakhtun Cultural Association, Islamabad, a literary and cultural organisation, Sial has kept a keen eye on the rapidly changing national and international scenario. In all of his poems, he has analysed issues surrounding the Pashtun community, suggesting ways to peace and stability.

 The last of his titles is mainly focused on themes pertaining to peace, claiming that militants will never be successful in their nefarious designs against the Pashtuns, that permanent peace will prevail, that Pashtun’s cultural identity will remain intact as it has done over thousands of years.

 Khan Mohammad Tanha’s poetry collection, Da Baarudo Pah Logu Ke (In the Smoke of Explosives) is a venture of a young poet putting to verse the adverse effects of militancy.

 Published under the auspices of Khushhal Adabi wo Saqafati Jirga, Nowshera, the book’s foreword has been written by the late Ajmal Khattak. In a quatrain he says that it is unfortunately our own people who destroyed our mosques and hujras, who disfigured our peaceful cultural image. In one poem he says that perhaps we both share the same blood, the same piece of land and the same wish in our hearts and minds to reform this beleaguered Pashtun society. “Perhaps we share the same path to bringing change, the difference is that you have preferred the sword and I took up the pen. If change is our end and you too think so then let’s come to the peace jirga and save this pure land from the oppressors. After all, you are Pashtuns and Pashtuns never defile the invitation for peace negotiations.” The poet has not restricted himself only to Pashtuns but has also highlighted the miseries of the people of Iraq and Afghanistan.

 Amjad Shahzad’s bold attempt, Nah (No), occupies a distinct position among the newly launched poetry collections as he has presented not just a mundane account of the bizarre situation around him but has given a new twist to resistance poetry in Pashto. He outright rejects any tolerance for miscreants. He believes in what Khushhal Khan Khattak once said in a couplet, that a terrorist should at no cost be tolerated in the country even if a pious man recommends his stay. As the title of the book suggests, Shahzad is uncompromising when it comes to peace. In the poem titled “Tragedy,” he says, “Here people live in the shadows of hatred, why do you care for dawn, Amjad may be killed for telling the truth.”

 Another poet, Israr Atal, in his collection Ziarray Mazeegaray Ph Pkhawar Ke Dey, focuses on Peshawar city which has been the cultural hub for Pashtuns for centuries. His poem, Khudiaya Daa Bas Ah Kegee (O God! What Will Happen Now) received great applause for its unique expression. Israr recalls the glorious past of Peshawar when it used to be the city of flowers; today one can only see and smell explosions and its land is strewn with blood and flesh.

This article was originally published in dawn's literary magazine  books and authors

item.title: Milestones in Pashto literature
item.dc:creator: shinwari
item.content:encoded:
The history of the written word in Pashto goes back to 522-486 BCE with the discovery of a three-line poetic piece engraved on the rock of a mountain near Baghistan, Iran. If so it can be assumed that the written history of Pashto is 2,500 years old. However, researchers have identified three periods of the history of Pashto literature.

The first period begins with Ameer Korer Ghuri (747 CE), the second period starts with Bayazid Ansari (1535-1579) popularly known as `Pir Roshan` or the enlightened Pir, while the third period — according to one theory — began in 1908 when Rahat Zakheli Baba (1884-1963) wrote the first ever short story in Pashto language.Hamish Khalil, in his book Da Qalam Khawandaan (A directory of Pakhtun men of letters), has mentioned around 3,000 Pakhtun poets and writers between 1800 and 1975 who were prolific writers and have contributed to Pashto language and literature by writing books both in prose and poetry.

Pashto has never enjoyed official recognition and patronage, as it has never been the court language despite the fact that Ahmed Shah Abdali and Sher Shah Suri were Pakhtun kings; even they preferred Persian to Pashto for court proceedings and other matters.After the advent of the British, Pashto language and literature took a new turn. The British and Orientalists rediscovered literary giants like Khushhal Khan Khattak (1613-1690), Rahman Baba (1653-1711) and other classical poets and writers.Pakhtun writers and poets of the early 20th century began to express their feelings and emotions by bringing out literary magazines and pamphlets.

These journals not only helped Pashto to flourish but also brought about a change in the social, political and cultural vision of the Pakhtun nation. Translations were also done into Pashto from English.

Nun Paroon was one such literary magazine published from New Delhi in pre-partition era edited by the founding director of the Pashto Academy University of Peshawar, Maulana Abdul Qadir (1905-1969).Abdul Ghafoor alias Saidu Baba brought out the first ever Pashto monthly magazine in the pre-partition era titled Islam in 1884. In addition to Pushto, it used to publish scholastic and literary translations from Persian as well as Urdu classics. It was followed by Anjuman, Payam-i-Haq and Anjuman-i-Himayat-i-Islam.One cannot term these journals as being pure literary as they carried religious teachings too. Often they would not touch upon social issues or criticize government policies. After all, the environment was not conducive for freedom of expression under the British Raj.Many attempts at bringing out weekly newspapers and monthly journals were made but each one faced closure following the imposition of the 1910 Press Act. Abdul Ghaffar Khan (Bacha Khan), founder of the Khudai Khidmatgaar Tehrik, launched the first ever full-fledged Pashto magazine Pakhtun under the auspices of Anjuman Islah-i-Afaghina in 1927 to bring about a qualitative change in the outlook of the Pakhtun.

Prominent men of letters affiliated with the Tehrik would contribute their poetic and prose works in it but in 1930 Bacha Khan was arrested and the magazine was closed down.It was re-launched in 1931 under Abdul Khaliq Khaleeq and after several closures and re-launches, it was finally banned it in 1948.

With the publication of Pushto weeklies and monthlies like Sailaab (1931), Strray Mashay (1932), Azad Pakhtun (1932), Rahbar (1936) and Jamhooriat (1937), the scope of public awareness was enhanced.

Social issues became dazzling headlines and fiery editorials were printed. After partition, Abdul Haleem Asr (1910-1978) brought out the first Pashto weekly magazine Insaaf in 1948 from Mardan which published literary pieces and research articles aimed at promoting the region`s language and literature.

A government sponsored magazine Jamhoor-i-Islam (later renamed Abaseen) attracted writers and poets as it paid well and also highlight the government`s policies and programmes. Apart from these magazines, some Urdu daily newspapers like Shabaz, Anjaam and Baang-i-Harum also catered to Pashto readers by publishing a separate supplement.

The magazines Pakhto and Qand also contributed to modern Pashto literature. So much so that two professors have recently submitted their doctorate theses to the University of Peshawar on the role and contributions of these historic literary journals.

Today more than 100 literary magazines are published in Pashto from various places like Afghanistan and of course from Peshawar, Kohat, Mardan, Bannu, D.I.Khan, Charsadda, Karachi and Quetta. Most of these literary magazines have gone out of print due to financial constraints, yet they are considered milestones in the history of Pashto literature.Despite various problems, it is the poets and writers who have had kept the Pashto language alive and enriched.

Originally published in Dawn’s books and authors

item.title: Jirga vs. Brehon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Jirga is a negotiating body and is one of the longest standing cultural traditions and effective forums in Pakhtoon society, settling hundreds of disputes and conflicts every day. Comprised of the most respected, influential and honoured elders of the community known as ‘Masharan’, they use their skills, judgement and wisdom in decision making, ensuring fairness and peace amongst neighbours and tribes across Pashtun regions. The ‘Jirga’ tradition existed in Pashtun culture long before the advent of Islam to South Asia. Upon its arrival, Islamic teachings were amalgamated into the system in a positive manner: thus the Masharan proceeded to make decisions in light of the Qur’an, Sunnah and Pashtun custom combined.  Complex cases and disputes are solved through negotiation and collective decision making; cases that might otherwise take years to solve through the official British judicial system.

In ancient Ireland a similar system was in place long before Christian, Danish and Anglo/Norman invasion. Its development began around 2,300 BC. Desire for justice has always suffused the collective consciousness of Irish people and Brehon law was a highly respected and dominant force in Irish society. Bearing notable resemblance to the Pashtun Jirga system, it too was a negotiating forum based on ideals of fairness, equality and justice for all. Without need of government enforcement, police force or prison, this oral tradition was communicated from one generation to the next placing supreme importance to the family unit within a tribal interconnecting network. The wise, highly respected and honourable law makers were known as ‘Brehon’ and their opinions and decisions were accepted. Nonetheless, any member of the community could put forward an opinion. In such cases the disputing parties could deliberate until an agreement was established, thus ‘negotiation’ was at the core of the system. If disputing parties failed to reach an agreement, the Brehon would have the final say. These decisions were based on high moral values therefore the Brehon carried persuasive power.

Some of the main features of Brehon law were:

Moral Code/Social Unit:

The social structure in Ireland was made up of families, their tribe and sub-groups. Therefore the tribe as a ‘unit’ were responsible and liable for any wrongdoing or offence by any individual member.

Honour Price:

People of high rank within the community were judged at a higher standard regarding how damages were calculated allowing for a fair means of penalty. Each were judged according to their rank, worth and stock.

Restitution:

Compensation and restoration to any injured party was the foundation concept and value of Brehon law. Paying debts to society, having negotiated by democratic means, cultivated a system of fairness and justice for all.

 Rights of women:

Brehon law was one of the most forward thinking judging bodies regarding rights of women. Women were considered equal to men and were allowed to divorce on specific grounds such as the husband’s failure to support the family, impotence or striking his wife. There are also records of female Brehon law makers.

In complex areas such as homicide and land issues, punishment and law enforcement becomes more intricate and detailed. (I will discuss these issues in a future post)

In the seventeenth century, the British invaded Ireland taking over the ruling and running of the country. They forcefully abolished Brehon law forcing a ban on the practice and subsequently reinforced their own British law system. Yet records indicate that the majority of Irish people secretly conducted the ancient Brehon way to settle disputes, believing it to be a fairer and more just practice and tradition.

item.title: Interview with Muhammad Rome
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Rome
item.content:encoded:
(June 2013)

 

On the final day of my recent trip to Pakistan, I was privileged to be granted an interview with Muhammad Rome, a man whose initiative, passion and aspirations are achieving momentous results in pursuit of the revival and restoration of Pashtun arts and culture. A mere glance at his professional career to date proves his authoritative knowledge on all aspects of Pashtun culture. While our informal discussion covered a variety of topics such as Landay or ‘Tappa’, the revered poet Khushal Khan Khattak, and the  highly respected and powerful figure of the ‘mother’ within the Pashtun family unit, the majority of our discussion evolved around the current situation regarding arts and culture. I asked Muhammad how the actions, activities, beliefs and opposition from groups of Militants and extremists are affecting the present day state of Pashtun arts and cultural activities in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Afghanistan.

 

Muhammad Rome:

 

“Every work of art touches sublimity when there is peace. If you take the example of Pashtun society and their work of art and creativity it is noticed that the societal creativity has flourished with them from the very beginning of their social life. Over the centuries Pashtun society is evolved in the environment of ‘resistance’. Throughout the course of their history, their land has been invaded or internal conflicts took place that resulted into the loss of social fabric. But they were able to remould and started afresh. In such circumstances a social psyche of resistance evolved. This characteristic of resistance is aptly portrayed in Pashtuns’ works of arts. The current militancy in the Pashtun belt on both sides of Durand Line is traced back to 1980s, when the so called Afghan Jihad was fought against the then Soviet Union. From that time onwards the onslaught of artists and works of creativity have been continued. Musicians and singers were forced to leave their countries. Naghama, Nashanas, a renowned name of Pashto music, from Afghanistan, left the country due to the prevailing uncertainty there. Creative and cultural activities were once the hallmark of Afghanistan. They were instrumental in binding the society, aesthetically. But due to the war and ensuing militancy the social and cultural bonds were deteriorated and eventually lost. Due to the disruption of artistic and cultural communication systems, celebrating music, arts and literary gatherings have drastically diminished. Listening to music on the radio and other forms of media was very common but slowly and gradually due to various factors took a back seat. There was a time when dancers and musicians visited villages and towns and were performing in the open. People thronged into these shows and women were watching them from the roof tops. Then there were regular music concerts all over Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistani side of the border.”

“Coming back to the musicians who were threatened to quit, other reputed names are Sardar Ali Takkar and Haroon Bacha who were both on threat: so they decided to leave the country. These names are legends, everybody knew of them very well. If a performance by any of these artists was announced, people would travel from far and wide to attend. These performers are masters of their art. When they were still living in this region, upcoming musicians and singers were learning from them. But now this tradition is lost. I remember as a youth, my mother enjoying listening to good music on the radio. There were various other cultural manifestations but due to the indoctrination of Salafist Islam these manifestations were drastically affected and as a result a major disconnection took place. This disconnect has created a vacuum. Extremists have exploited this situation by preaching Islamic Ideology and Jihad. When the Maulanas began to preach on their illegal FM radios, people listened to them and were exploited by them and as a result, this change took place. The militarization has many other factors but that is out of context here.”

“Pashto music has survived against all odds. Currently new musicians and singers have come up. Pashto music is getting very popular in the youth. New practices are made and have enriched Pashto music. It is very encouraging and you can say a new beginning for the Pashto music.” “But if the militancy continues, which seems unlikely to abate, and if the threat to the musicians persists it might have a long lasting negative impact on the future of Pashto music.”    

 

“On the subject of Poetry: The creation of poetry is spontaneous and can come to a poet anytime or anywhere. The feelings are expressed regardless what the situation is. Every creative art has rooted in its age and time. The poetry of today explicitly expresses the prevailing situation in Pashtun society. Across Pakhtunkhwa, poets have responded to the situation in their poetry, even though that the traditional poetic recitations gatherings have grossly diminished. It is not only because of the fear of the people, but the actual ‘involvement’ in the arts has been lost. Large gatherings of any kind cannot be arranged because of the threats, perceived or real. Art works and creative practices have been targeted such as the bombing of cinemas, destruction of museums and stealing of art works, over the last many decades. The forces of darkness have been trying to create mayhem, trying to create a disconnection with cultural practices. This chaos has been created consciously and systematically by them.”

 

Talking about the militancy during the so called Jihad against the Soviet Red army, Muhammad Rome said, “During those days the extremists were called as Mujahedeen and Taliban and they were idealized. They were looked upon as almost sacred people. They were or made the heroes of the people and society. Now they are detested. Nobody likes them. Thus, a shift has happened. Even the traditional Mullahs cannot enjoy the power they once had, although they would rather follow Islamic ideology.”

“Durand Line divides Pakhtun land and population between Pakistan and Afghanistan. The population and land of Pakhtuns are further divided into different administrative units, with different rules and laws, within Pakistan. Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) has laws that have no matching in the world, grossly violating human rights. This division and inhuman laws are exploited by all those who want to create terror. This division has ruptured the society of Pakhtuns. Their social division existed since long. Although they share the same language, culture, history and traditions. But their tribal kind of living and internal feuds have divided the society from within. The great Khushal Khan Khattak has aptly described this situation;

 

PH YAWA JABA WAYAL SARA PUKHTOO KRO,

WALE HIS LH BALA NH SHO KHABARDAR

A rough translation will be like;

Though we speak the same language, Pashto

But utterly unaware of each other plight.

 

The social and land division have driven them so far apart that neighbours had no idea what was happening in other Pashtun regions. But due to the prevailing situation of militancy throughout in Pukhtuns’ belt a sense of ‘oneness’ is arousing in them. In the present day there are numerous songs becoming popular that convey the message of ‘unity’ and peace. So what does this mean? It expresses the collective consciousness of the people in sharp contrast to extremism being imposed upon them”.  

 

Muhammad Rome has established Pakhtunkhwa Cultural Foundation (PCF), based in Peshawar. Encouragement of the exchange of musicians, poetry and books is of primary importance. Muhammad Rome is one of the founding members of Swastu Arts and Culture Association (SACA) in Swat is moving forward and is a vibrant, active association. Muhammad Rome’s associations were recently the first, in reviving cultural activities, to arrange concerts and gatherings of a cultural nature in Peshawar and other parts of Pakhtunkhwa. They are in the process of trying to gain the confidence of the people towards social interaction and towards the celebration of the rich, ancient and unique legacy of arts and culture of Pashtuns.

Muhammad Rome (details of professional career to date):

Master in English Literature,

Currently ED of Pakhtunkhwa Cultural Foundation (PCF), based in Peshawar,

Email: pcf.pakhtunkhwa@gmail.com, muhammadrome@gmail.com.

Coordinator of Pakhtoonkhwa Arts and Culture Project, Islamabad

Co-Coordinator of Suvastu Arts and Culture Association (SACA)

An active social and political activist

item.title: Military operation in SWA and its impact on education
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Noman Burki
item.content:encoded:
“The hell doors knocker” – South Waziristan Agency, is one of the small, yet beautiful heavens on earth, enriched with lots of natural resources. The people of SWA are straightforward, not well educated, yet carry out their business in order to keep the wheels of life turning. They want to live independently and at peace. ‘Peace’ is their first choice: not the gun. These people are warriors by birth, not terrorists. “Attan” is one of the eminent cultures of these people.

South Waziristan Agency is comprised of three main divisions: Wanna, Ladha and Sarwekai. The famous tribes of the area are: Wazir, Mehsud and Burki’s. In general, Wazir’s cover the Wanna division while Mehsud’s and Burki’s cover the Ladha and Sarwekai division. SWA is attached to the Afghan border, linking the adjacent Bermal area of Waziristan with Afghanistan. In the eyes of internal and external establishments, SWA is regarded as ‘the hub of terrorists’ and by using this excuse the fore mentioned establishments are hatching conspiracies to insure instability along this area of the tribal belt.  Although continuous efforts are being made to eliminate terrorists for the past eight to ten years from this area: so far, there has been no distinct progress. The IDP’s are tired of this worthless operation.  SWA is one of the affected tribal areas, particularly the Mehsud area, which constitutes a large area of Waziristan. War on terror affected the Mehsud tribe politically, socially, morally and economically.

In the field of education, the already backward Mehsud tribe have been severely affected and chances of rehabilitation are very poor. All educational institutions including colleges, government high schools, government middle schools, government primary, both boys and girls schools, have remained closed for the past six to seven years and there is no available platform to raise the talents of these young people, except Madrassa’s. The buildings of these educational institutions have been damaged by the Pakistan Army in their efforts to eliminate terrorism, and as a result, some of these school buildings have now become occupied by the Army, who use them as military camps.

This situation has not only darkened the future of Mehsuds tribesman but has also produced a situation whereby young people have become ‘easy prey’ for terrorists. This denotes the contradictions between the policy and actions of the government: they are saying one thing, yet doing another. If the government wants to achieve success in the so-called ‘war on terror’, then the government will have to create a safe and proper educational atmosphere for the Mehsuds tribesmen. In some areas where IDPs have settled, there is a continuous curfew-like situation and school going children are receiving an education under the shadow of guns, which gives them the impression that the ‘gun’ is more important than the ‘pen’.

Moreover, the Pakistan army have recently taken steps to reopen educational institutions in some areas, but these efforts are still not sufficient and the government will need to do more by re-addressing these issues in the field of education. These alarming situations can be changed and should be changed by establishing civilian rights and removing illiterate gunmen from the area, because everything they do, they do with the help of a gun.
