wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
It’s a fact that Nehru was infamous for his arrogance and his inabilities towards understanding of tribesmen, due to his arrogance Nehru was even criticized by his congress men, but Olaf Caroe is also a very controversial figure as he was being accused of unfairly close to Muslim League and therefore he was replaced as a governor in mid-1947 by Rob Lockhart.
It would be very useful for the readers if any credible reference to the letter was also mentioned.

Understanding the mental make up of tribes or tribal people living in FATA is not every man's affair. Nehru had read some books on frontier tribes which lead him to believe that as frontier tribesmen being hostile to invaders would wellcome him as leader bent upon freeing them from foreign subjugation.He had misread the situation; Bacha khan popularity had bit diminished and muslim league had gained roots.Then there were pashtoons who were hostile to British raj but looked down upon Badshah khan policy of non-voilence and congress affiliations.Molvi Abdul kalam azad claims in his book INDIA WINS FREEDOM that he opposed Nehru to visit NWFP and especially tribal area at that very time. Might be Nehru had some scheme in his mind to create fissure in tribal belt first and then involve afghan govt... Thanks to tribal people , Nehru scheme foiled. What Nehru and congress did to BACHA KHAN and Pashtoon cause at last moments of united India is an open fact.Simply we pashtoons were thrown before the wolves.

item.title: Af-Pak-US Triangle and 2014 Scenario
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Arif Tangi
item.content:encoded:
The post 2014 scenario in Afghanistan is broadly portrayed as a nightmare. While U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry in his recent visit to Pakistan has already hinted a “draw-down”, there are widespread apprehensions among the analysts of repetition of the early 1990’s civil war with ethnic, religious, sectarian and proxy war contenders for the thrown of Kabul. The picture is further portrayed fizzy as U.S–Afghanistan Strategic Partnership Agreement is yet to evolve into a comprehensive bilateral agreement about the possible presence of US troops in Afghanistan after 2014.

Whatever the situation might be one thing is sure that the three countries US, Afghanistan and Pakistan are either the direct beneficiaries of any peace-building process or they will be bearing the brunt of a possible long-term continuation of the conflict and terrorism. In the last 10 years or so we have been witnessing distrust on either side of the Afghanistan-Pakistan-United States (Af-Pak-US) triangle and it is important to learn lessons from the past before embarking on any post-2014 journey for the region.

Significant in this regard is US model of the Af-Pak. Since the term was first used by Richard Holbrooke, the Obama administration's Special Representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, the region was conceived as a “single theatre of operation” to “disrupt, dismantle and prevent” Al-Qaeda. But the term had other implications too. It was supposed to serve as a democratic model to slowly and gradually bring democratic forces in the two countries together through people-to-people contact, businesses and to some extent military partnership. It was probably envisioned that democracies in the two neighboring countries will open up avenues for dialogue, mediation and reconciliation and thus reducing the chances for not-state actors to have sanctuaries in either of the countries. However, lacking the vision both Karzai and Zardari administrations fell prey to their internal political compulsions and cooperation between the two countries could not evolve. Consequently both the countries blame each other of sponsoring terrorism and interference and due to which many areas of FATA and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are now virtually under the control of the Taliban.

The Af-Pak model was conceived in the broader regional and international interests of the super power i.e. the US. However, like all plans challenges surface when it comes to implementation. The plan largely depended on the holistic processes that have been shaped by diverse factors within the triangle as well as with the inclusion and exclusion of other players regionally and internationally. One such intrusion in the triangle is the Indian influence in Afghanistan and its support and training for the Afghan National Security Forces.  This will remain the bone of contention between Afghanistan and Pakistan until the tension between India and Pakistan is normalized to the extent that it may not disturb the trust between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Otherwise the security apparatus in Pakistan will continue its reluctance to go after terrorists’ sanctuaries on the pretext that growing Indian influence in Afghanistan will greatly undermine Pakistan’s own security concerns not only on the eastern border but also on the western side and beyond the Durand Line.

The current apprehensions are largely founded on the impression that Afghanistan is largely dependent on international security assistance and if such assistance is withdrawn, non-state actors would not only be able to destabilize the country but will also ignite ethnic, religious and proxy conflicts. It is, therefore, very important to scientifically calculate the strength and weakness of the Afghan state, its economy, its security apparatus and the magnitude of threats it is supposed to face in case of a possible withdrawal of international assistance. Significant in this regards is Afghan Presidential election to be held in April 2014. We had been witnessing in the previous elections that electorate was manipulated and massive rigging and corruptions scandals were reported. Afghans want peace and prosperity and free, fair and transparent elections would be the key to bring creative and constructive leadership to the front who would be able to deliver in times of extreme crisis. 

While we may yet to decide between a “withdrawal” and a “draw-down” by the US, one thing is imminent that the NATO forces are supposed to withdraw and they will need the same route through which they have been provided all the supply. In the recent past NATO supply has been continually halted by terrorists’ attacks and by Pakistan’s own security concerns. Moreover, the right-wing political parties in Pakistan are specifically mindful of this supply line and some of them are now ruling Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. These supply lines pass through FATA, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the Pashtun areas of Baluchistan. In these areas Taliban operatives have sanctuaries, networks and parallel governments. These areas are politically marginalized and have been partially devastated by terrorism, military operations, internal displacement and natural disasters. In the past these areas have been largely neglected and were not made stakeholders in the decision-making process. It is, therefore, pertinent to mention that in the wake of NATO‘s withdrawal we may likely to see challenges of unprecedented magnitude which may totally or substantively jeopardize peace in the region.

The possibility for sustainable peace exists within the Afghan-Pakistan-US (Af-Pak-US) triangle and trust deficit on each side of this triangle has devastating implications not only for the three countries but also for the entire region. It is quite obvious that an Afghan, an American and a Pakistani are suffering from lack of peace or conversely they will benefit from peace. The choice is simple.

{mso-style-name:"Table Normal"; mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0; mso-tstyle-colband-size:0; mso-style-noshow:yes; mso-style-priority:99; mso-style-parent:""; mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt; font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;} </style> <![endif]--> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Jarga: the power tool to solve, resolve, negotiate and implement, has been practiced by Pashtuns for centuries. </span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> The term ‘Jarga’ literally means: farming a circle, and within Pakhtun culture and society, its concept is understood in terms of ‘the circle of men’… a system conducive to the upholding of social, moral and economic order while concurrently maintaining and preserving Pashtun culture.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> Within pakhtun customs, the Jarga system has the power to initiate a step towards peace and reconciliation, even if the conflict is as serious as war. Jarga can bring hope and resolution to an animus situation because it is the complete unconditional transfer of power and compromise on the ‘stance’ of the parties involved.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> The Jarga council consists of respected and esteemed members of the local community who are undisputed and impartial in their judgement: members (elders) who are capable of taking all matters, opinions and considerations into account.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>Through wisdom, negotiation and deliberation, the council will reach a decision which remains unavoidable and non- contentious for all parties concerned.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> The council of Jarga does not comprise of the ordinary, common people of the community. There is a criterion, conditions and attributions required in order to become a member of the Jirga panel of negotiators.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> The Jarga council consists of a body of community elders, whose respect and influence within the society, along with a solid grounding and good understanding of Rivaj (culture and traditions) permits them to make decisions, based on cultural and moral values: a person with good communication skills who can negotiate with powerful arguments and at the same time, be a ‘well-wisher’ within the community.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> This respected council of elders not only confer to solve conflicts but also apply some rules to lead Jarga to a conclusive ending. Before the formal discussion is stated by the Jarga, both parties are subjected to give ‘pledge.’ Normally this means relinquishing, temporarily, of land, arms or money, which is subsequently taken into custody by the Jarga. If the issue is not solved after many attempts then each party is asked to take 70 oaths on the holy books, (which must be taken by 70 people). Inevitably, this brings an end to the problem because in Pakhtun culture religion is never compromised.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> The Jarga council analyse issues from different perspectives through arguments and discussions. The first hearing is performed like any formal court hearing. Following on from that, social and cultural angles of the issues are examined.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> Jarga members, try to maintain collective respect throughout the process.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>They never demoralize. They try their best to offer respect and as a result, Jarga is held in the most respected position within Pakhtun culture. By the sheer fact that Jirga elders are members of the corresponding community they represent, insures the collective privacy of the decisions, therefore maintaining the discretion of local community business and keeping matters ‘within the walls.’
This ancient element of tribal culture, which has withstood the test of time and still thrives within many parts of Pashtun society today, often invokes questioning from other societies whom envisage their own ‘state run’ structure and concept of law to be<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>more acceptable within the norms of society. Yet this element of tribal Pakhtun culture has managed to retain its power and success amidst the global dominance of established norms concerned with practice of law.</span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><b><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The following points outline the main principles of Jarga:</span></b></p> <p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <i>Representation of the different tribes in Jarga allows them to understand and highlight cultural values collectively, and to remember their identity. Jarga represents Unity.</i>
<i>Jarga is a sitting offering many suggestions and solutions to a single problem: the participants can easily choose the best, most favourable and most uncomplicated solution.</i></span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <i>Permanence of the culture and traditional values of Pashtuns is a property of the Jarga, which ensures participation in continuing cultural transformation from generation to generation.</i></span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <i>The Jarga council denounce hypocrisy. Face to face arguments and hearing makes a clear difference between water and milk. Thus, Jarga gives support and moral value to being truthful.</i></span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> <i>As jarga is the process of ‘current and active’ attempt to solve problems, it lends to better circumstances and opportunity to realise each other’s intentions.</i></span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> </span></p> <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The law FCR (Frontier crime regulation) implemented in Pakhtun tribal areas of Pakistan does not offer court rights to the tribal community, which is again making a way for jarga to remain a prominent solution towards problems in the society. Small crimes like robbery, stealing and other social issue can easily be dealt with through the Jarga. However, in the case of warring tribes, the Government acts as a third party, (securing political interest), which as a consequence affects the authority and durability of the jarga.
Jarga involves members of local communities within Pashtun society in its decisions, offering a live stage and a means to ‘speak, listen, negotiate, deliberate and resolve problems. <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>Jirga believes in total freedom of speech, thus lessening the possibility of conspiracy.</span></p>

item.title: 'The Pathans' by Ghani Khan: A commentary
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ghani Khan ‘The Pathans’ (published 1947 by University Book Agency, Peshawar)

Ghani Khan (1914-1996) was born in Hashtnagar (Charsadda), Pakhtunkhwa. Ghani was the eldest son of the great Pashtun political and spiritual leader Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan (aka: Bacha Khan) (1890-1988), who dedicated his life for the freedom, education, empowerment and cause of Pashtun people. Renowned and revered for his peaceful campaign of social and political reform, Bacha Khan was nonetheless incarcerated throughout his life, ill-treated and hounded by the then tyrannical British Colonial governors. Bacha Khan’s struggle for his people was advocated through ‘non-violent’ means, earning him the title: ‘non-violent soldier of Islam. (More about Bacha Khan at a later date)

One of the most gifted and loved 20th Century Pashto language poets: Ghani was also an artist, sculptor, politician and philosopher. While approaching many themes in his work, it is Ghani’s portrayal of his complex and problematic relationship with the ‘Mullah,’ (Religious leader), which captivates the imagination. Through wisdom, satire and wit, Ghani questions the authority, sincerity and position of the Mullah in Pashtun society, deeming his ideology and teachings to be one of hypocrisy and ignorance. Much of Ghani’s poetry embodies a profound love for God, reflected in Sufi devotional poetry such as that of Jalaladdin Rumi (1207-1273) and Rahman Baba (approx. 1652-1711).

 While I aim to discuss Ghani’s life and poetry at a later stage, in this essay I endeavour to review Ghani’s English language book: ‘The Pathans;’ (written in 1947). In this work, Ghani discloses an intimate portrayal of the Pashtun man offering the reader a glimpse of various aspects, principles and moral codes personified in ‘Pakhtunwali’ (the Pashtun code of honour). Ghani suggests that these values, customs and particularly the idea of ‘honour’ are inherent in the consciousness of Pashtuns: so much so, that the Pashtun is driven to avenge his honour if needs be. Ghani approaches his subject under various headings such as: History; Folk Songs; An Incident; Customs; Priest, Magic & Charms; Revenge; and Politics. With a touching and at times humorous account, Ghani concludes with a tribute to one of the most exemplary Pashtun men of all time: his father: Bacha Khan.

Ghani begins by expressing the paradoxical nature of the Pashtun man, which he refers to as one of:  ‘complicated simplicity.’ If we are to understand the laws of the Pashtun, we need to learn of his customs. Ghani tells us ‘the Pashtun will forgive you anything if you do it bravely enough, and like the Greeks, he is a great poet and warrior: almost all his wars are over women.’ He tells us the Pashtun is a ‘temperamental neighbour who might become a loving friend, or a deadly enemy. His violent nature, strong body and tender heart make a very unstable combination for living but an ideal one for poetry and colour.’

On the subject of ‘honour,’ Ghani recounts the story of a ‘proud Khan’ who shot another Khan who had insulted his father. (in Pakhtunwali, ‘Badal;’ meaning ‘revenge,’ must be sought to avenge any insult or harm caused to one’s family or tribe) Ghani tells us, ‘the blood of a Pashtun cannot be paid for except with blood:’ giving clear indication that these are not state laws, but the laws of the people: ‘A Pashtun knows his customs before he knows how to eat. It is bred in him. For cruel and oppressive as the customs and laws are, they are the only binding force of our culture.’ Ghani articulates his philosophy on this subject where he states:

 ‘When a law is bred into the very fibre of a race it becomes a custom. A man gives his children not only the shape of his nose and the cranks in his character, he also teaches them his fears and forebodings, his songs and curses. He moulds his child as nearly as he can to his own shape.’

When Ghani approaches the subject matter of ‘Politics:’’ he does so philosophically and with a twinge of humour where he writes:

‘Politics today do what religion did five hundred years ago. They are merely a system which men have developed, whereby they pay for their stupidities by giving crafty wise men and earnest fools the power to rule them. For every man must rule or be ruled. There is no third way unless you are a poet or a lunatic,’

In dealing with the subject of: failure of the social system to provide for his family, Ghani writes:

‘When a political arrangement decides to starve him and over-feed another, the Pashtun shoots holes into it. He would rather steal than beg. He would rather face the anger of God and man than the shame and disgrace of poverty.’

While Ghani recounts various stories, analogies and poetry to portray an understanding and description of the character of the Pashtun in this book, it is perhaps the final chapter which is most revealing and in many ways: touching, in the representation of his father: Bacha Khan.

Broaching the subject of his father’s socio-political struggle and the birth of the movement of:  ‘Khudai Khidmatgar,’(Servants of God) Ghani recounts:

“The sole role of the political department of the Government of India under the British was to try to teach the hawks of Khyber the wretched ways of the crow and the vulture. It seduced the lowest and the greediest of the tribe and gave them importance and bought influence for them. A tool must be important and influential. All influence in the tribes belonged to the Khan and the Priest (Mullah) – one is the lord of this world, the other claims the lordship of the next.”

Ghani explains that at this time ‘the Empire was safe and the Pashtun damned. Then, it was in a little village in the prosperous Peshawar valley that the first Khudai Khidmatgar was born.’  Ghani lovingly discusses his grandfather: Behram Khan, by recalling:

‘He had no feuds – a unique distinction for a Khan, because he had forgiven all his enemies. Behram never told a lie, he did not know how to. He liked the British who ruled him though he could never remember their names. He was painfully honest; therefore the people loved him.’

Equally touching is Ghani’s account of his father Bacha Khan where he states:

“Being the youngest child he was his mother’s pet. The boy was kind and clean and six-foot-three. He loved his old father and always gave strange, noble reasons for doing things. The old Khan forgave him everything, even refusing a commission in the Army. His beautiful old mother supported the boy and seemed to understand him better than he. She understood everything the child did.”

Bacha Khan

 

Ghani recounts how after the death of his wife, Bacha Khan ‘drowned his sorrow in work and service: he found a new love – his people.’ He began talking to the people, drawing attention to the misery and darkness of their lives, opening schools and dealing with the British rulers on their behalf. Acknowledging the high illiteracy rate amongst Pashtuns, Bacha Khan went from village to village promoting education. Because of his power and popularity, he became a thorn in the side of the British and was thus condemned to years of torture in various prisons. Yet Ghani writes: ‘His spirit was like steel. His blue eyes were proud of their suffering and determined and cold.’ Ghani concludes by stating that:

‘Bacha Khan is the politics of the Pashtun. He understands the Pashtun and they understand him. Bacha Khan discovered that the kindest strength is the greatest strength, that the only way to be brave is to be right; that a clean dream is dearer than life and the soft eyes of your children. These are the things he has taught the Pashtun.’

(All the above quotes taken from: Ghani Khan ‘The Pathans’ (published 1947 by University Book Agency, Peshawar)

item.title: Afghan Artist: Azad Rasam
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Like millions of refugees fleeing Afghanistan, Rasam and his family made their way to America after the Russian invasion of 1979. They came to America with little: just the clothes on their backs, very little money and one empty suitcase full of endless dreams for a new life. At first, while growing up in northern Philadelphia, Rasam experienced an identity crisis. He felt a passionate longing to "fit in" as an American, while the memories of his childhood in Afghanistan continued to resonate with him. It was precisely these deep impressions of Afghan culture that came to define him: the realisation, discovery, and recognition of his true identity in his art. In 2005 Rasam returned to his homeland of Afghanistan where he lived and worked. This experience offered him the chance to get a closer look at the culture, society and life in Afghanistan after a gruelling 30 years of war, chaos and suffering, witnessed in his home Country.

Azad Rasam

Rasam was utterly amazed at what he found in the myriad faces of prolonged years of devastation. Yet, even in the midst of all this turmoil, it was the people, the colour, the beauty of this culture that truly inspired him even more vehemently towards his artistic vision.

Rural Afghan Man, Charcoal & Pencil, A4, 2013

The Malik, colour pencil, 8x10

It was during this lived experience for the first time, after such a long time, he had the opportunity to see the people, the landscape: to hear the voices of the Afghan people up close and personal. A combination of his visit to Afghanistan along with his own life experiences has made him realize that his art is about the preservation of culture. Rasam's paintings are a glimpse into the world through an Afghan's eye. Rasam is predominantly a figurative artist. He paints with bold and bright colours. His work can be described as loose and refined at times. The work can take on an unfinished look occasionally with more focus on the energy of the brushwork. His portraits of Pashtun people, whether through the medium of pencil or paint, communicate a haunting quality: a sense of longing, and foreboding; yet embody an overwhelming sense of resolute and determination. Rasam’s connection to and longing for his home Country, always resonates through his work. Rasam paints from his studio in Oakland, California.

Portrait Sketch of Afghan Woman, Oil on Canvas, 16x20, 2012

Still Life Vase Lemon, Oil on Board, 16x20, 2012

See more at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/afghanpainter/

item.title: Khyal Taran: A Pashto Poem
item.dc:creator: Khyal Taran
item.content:encoded:
"Khyal Taran"

Khazan dh cha mani, gulrang bahaar dh cha laas k d?

Dh mosamono dh badloon ikhtiar dh cha laas k d?

 Wagam ba sok khatmawi? Sok bh bia wagmey rawali?

 Khawand ye sok d aw taqdir dh khaar dh cha laas k d?

 Janat bh sok gati aw sok bh dh dozakh khashaak wi?

Khuday-zda insaaf dagha dh noor aw naar dh cha laas k d?

 Chaa kara wrra nishta aw sok ye ph khwand-rang heraan di

Dh de watan dh zindagai mayar dh cha laas k d?

 Oor lagedalay d swazegu kho da soch na kawoo

Oba pre sok nooli aw soor angaar dh cha laas k d?

 Oor d aw shor d aw aahona di aw chaghey kreekey

Dh de manzar kasheed kawalo kaar dh cha laas k d?

 Khyala! Zbekhaley, saa-niwaley zindagi dh zama

Mina bh sok raakrri?

Qurban, qaraar dh cha laas k d?"

[hr align="center"]

English Translation by: Arbab Daud:

Autumn comes without guidance from anyone;

                 The blossoming spring can be controlled by no one

 The nature goes on its own,

 The change in seasons can be controlled by no one

 Nobody can cease the fragrance;

 Neither can anyone give birth to fragrance

 Who’s the proprietor of flowers?

 And the fortune of thorns is controlled by no one

 Who’ll win a seat in paradise?

 And who’ll be the fuel for hellfire

 It’s the prerogative of God only;

 The light and fire can be controlled by no one

 Some are searching a fistful of flour;

 While others are astounded by its delight

 Is there a standard of life here?

 Or the wealth distribution is controlled by no one

 The flames are enveloping us;

 While we aren’t able to realize it

 Nobody’s sprinkling water on it;

 As the bustling fire is controlled by no one

 There are blazing flames and glowing beams;

 There are grunts and earsplitting screams

 It’s picturing extreme selfishness

 The scenes are apparently controlled by no one

 Oh Khayal! Your life is just empty;

 Your life if without any breath

 Who can give you some love?

 The tranquility is controlled by no one.

[hr align="center"]

English Translation by Khyal Taran:

Who lets go the autumn? Who brings spring and beauty? Who brings change and order? Who owes this as duty?

Who chases away the bad smell? Who lets in fragrance back? Who writes the city's fortune? Who does it? For God's sake...

Who is martyred? Who is guttered? I just wonder, yes I wonder If someone could please tell me Who is wise? Who does blunder?

One starves to death Other luxuriates lust and taste and fun If life standard of both rich and poor 'll ever one

Burning to ashes are we Yet we hardly bother thinking Who helps the flames growing? And who is doing the water sprinkling?

Flames, terror, fires, cries, tears, sarrows That's what is seen Do we know who does all this? Who creates scene?

O Khyal! My life 's full of miseries, tears and sadness I'm looking for someone who has for me, love and happiness

item.title: Pakistan needs Inter-racial and Inter-faith Marriages
item.dc:creator: AD Babar
item.content:encoded:
We are well aware that Pakistan has been facing many issues, particularly ethnic conflicts, sectarian violence and social strands. Disharmony, biasness and hatred engulf the ethnic lines and sect differences. Quetta, karachi, Lahore are the worst affected cities. In such miserable plight, could anyone ask the Parents of a girl for marriage? And the feelings that go with "I love you, but I am Sunni?” So what are the consequences arising from this scenario: A couple love each other but hail from different ethnic backgrounds, therefore are deemed hapless to marry each other due to the social strands. In this patriarchal society even the male population cannot voice their opinions or human rights. Ultimately, the final decision rests with the parents and what they decide for their children. IF society follows the rational approach, it will enhance and change the political milieu which is directly influenced by social behavior. While much of the world is evolving towards greater gender balance, Pakistan and most Afghan regions remain stubbornly immovable, with relation to individual rights not just of females but males also.

 

To begin with, Quetta is facing two kinds of disharmony in relation to terrorism: (Pashtun + Hazara), and (Pashtun + Baloch + Hazara). Hazara neither trust Baloch nor Pashtun, the reason is simply that the nefarious designs of hand in glove Lashkar-e-Jhangvi are recruiting either Baloch or Pashtun in continuing Hazara genocide. Although the recruitment is coming largely from the Baloch belt, the Pashtun is also viewed with distrust due to the Taliban factor. (The majority of Taliban are installed in the Pashtun belt areas like Waziristan and the in-active Quetta Shura, either for good or bad, but for strategic purposes). Apart from Sunni-Saudi and Shia-Iran, it is also apparently aimed at sidelining the Baloch Conflict in Balochistan and creating strands in Quetta. Unfortunately, Lahore, Jhang, Faisalabad and Karachi face the same ill-fate, as is judged in Chanute near Faisalabad with my Shia fellow. Owing to the fear of a Sunni-populated city, he is engaged in tacit affairs, facing both social and domestic consequences. As required, they are likely to flee outside in order to settle together thus deviating from families with disobedience.

Likewise, as Hussain Nadim, my respected teacher mentions in his writing “I love her, but I can’t be with her, because I’m an Ahmadi, and she is a Sunni Muslim.” The same plight continues due to inter-racial and sectarian distrust. One of my social network friends from Quetta once stated: ‘I am Shia Hazara and could not find sources to make any headway with the loved one hailing from Pashtun ethnicity'.  What will happen if they tie the knot? Some are still of the view that interracial marriages will be a drawback to the norms and culture of a community. Can those who advocate this theory point to any culture of the world which is consistent? Indeed, now is the time for cultures to mold and transform into a new world of 'Digital Phase'. For instance, throughout history, all conquests, whether Romans, Alexander the Great, or Muslims, one of the first things to consolidate their empire was to allow intermarriages between different groups to create a homogenous societies and interdependencies.

The birth of Pakistan’s radicalism and differences might actually be traced back to the lack of intermarriages between different sectarian and ethnic groups. The more distance and isolation placed between different sects and ethnicities, the more suspicion and misconception will arise. Eventually, this will lead to hyper radicalization and violence between communities. Also, it has been proven throughout history that whoever opposed intermarriages created chaotic situations. For instance in the Western world, certain jurisdictions previously had regulations banning or restricting interracial marriage, including Germany during the Nazi period, South Africa under apartheid, and many states in the United States prior to a 1967 Supreme Court decision. It is wrong to blame one particular community as none of the sectarian communities be it Shia, Ahmadi, Sunni or any other are open to the idea of marrying outside the community. My teacher narrates this too.

The deliberate idea of marriage out of choice, and inter marriages among sects and ethnics also has a serious negative effect in society in the form of cheating, and extra marital affairs, which needs no further explanation, as it can be witnessed everywhere around us. This poses a serious question: “if Shias, Sunnis and Ahmadis can eat and drink together, sit in the same classrooms and live in the same neighborhoods, why can they not live together in a holy bond of marriage under the same roof?” Similarly on the lines of interracial marriages, if Rahul Gandhi, a member of the Indian Parliament, is the son of an Indian father Rajiv Gandhi and Italian mother Sonia Gandhi, and khan Abdul Ghani khan can tie the knot with a Parsi born Roshan, who are considered the cultural and nationalistic keepers, why can't the new generation of Pakistan and Afghans continue likewise?

Furthermore, it was found via social network survey that someone stated: “I hate my family because they do not care about me ...They present themselves as being liberal yet yield me to death in spite of knowing about my relationship with my cousin. Father hates the boy and I’m burnt with Papa ego... and Mama materialistic approach." Moreover, many more issues in relation to our sisters have yet to be seriously resolved both constitutionally and socially. For instance, the use of cell phones by females in our society has also become a matter of honor and they in response deserve to be killed to portray one’s bravery in doing so.

 

While politicians and people alike are quick to criticize drones and US foreign policy for destroying Pakistan, nobody is talking about the far more serious threat lying beneath the surface. Besides all the evils being hatched by feudal society, this concern is arguably one of the biggest eye-openers. This self-preserved culture has been dominating our society rather than laws.  Elders are given supreme power to decide for their children, sometimes assuming an aggressive stance, further deviating children from obedience.

Today's trend of independence needs the idea of individualism promoting inter-marriages in Pakistan both by social and governmental organizations to not only save thousands of people from destroying their lives, but to unite the whole country: Punjabis, Pashtuns, Sindhis, Balochs, Hazaras and other minorities, disregarding the fact of being Sunni, Shia, Ahmadi and so on.

It’s time to break the social trends which are becoming the main factor of political designs in our society. Social trends like self-preserved domestic honor, the so-called norms and the self-sighted codes. Liberation for each individual should be granted and honored. A rational change is mandatory to put the society on the right track.

item.title: EXPLOITATION WITH AN ISLAMIC FACE IS DESTROYING US
item.dc:creator: AD Babar
item.content:encoded:
The war against terrorism gives the impression of a never-ending war; This prolonged, impending dilemma it seems, will inevitably stall any positive progress and will further promote dire long-term consequences on a regional basis.

Regionally, since the inception of Pakistan the impression of imminent danger prevails for the 'Project Pakistan' runners, posing additional risk from the north east and north western sides of the border. For instance, Pakistan's apprehension concerning the extensive border line, stretching from Chitral to Chaman City of Balochistan Province, being claimed by Afghan authorities. The predicament is not over yet as ‘deep strategic play’ regarding regionality, remains fully active and thriving, thus counteracting the nationalistic cry.

Internally, in retrospect, Khan Abdul Ghafar Khan was among those first to vow allegiance by taking oath with patriotic principles toward Pakistan. Nonetheless, his ' Khudai Khidmatgars' were brutally killed; apparently on the orders of the then CM of NWFP ( Khyber Pakhtunkhwa). The plight was the same with Balochs and Sindhis. Seemingly, neither Jinnah as a Governor-General nor Liaqat Ali Khan as a prime minister heard any of the voices of the Country's Provinces. In other words, Pakistan came into being for those only hailing from elite classes. At the other side of the country, Nehru, since the beginning, and up until 17 years after Independence, stressed the need for democratic steps and tried to convince people that the key solution to the world's problems was to be found in socialism. And today, we witness clear evidence as India claims the title of: 'Largest democratic country of the world' in almost all strides. Besides that, India has amicable relations with the USA, Russia, and Israel, yet our policies made us solely dependent on the USA, not entirely as a result of their initiation, but mainly by the then rulers of our own country.

We are cutting our fingers by ourselves! Why? The concept that: "Islam is in Danger" had nothing to do with the double standards we pursued. Sending the so-called Jihadis to Afghanistan without registration of names has caused an environment of uncertainty. Now those very guns have turned toward Pakistan. The reason being that some wings were left with strange posture and some figures are sent under-ground and in-active. It should also be remembered that this state of affairs has brought colossal and collateral damages to the Country including the loss of more than 40 thousand lives of citizens, more than 5 thousands army personell, officials and politicians and furthermore caused in excess of 5 billion dollars of damage to infastructure. Therefore, is it fair to say that the war is being pushed onto Pakistan by the USA? Is it in fact our own fault, in light of the elements concerning the cold war? Since 9/11, everything has changed, yet we remain the same as in the past.

One could add an even longer list of events considering consequences and outcomes.Without resting on the question for very long, we can safely pronounce that Pakistan is on the margin of decline. For a start, let's consider drone attacks and constant warm-ups by the US; our weak economy; insurgency and target killing of Shia; extra-judicial killings; and a weekly dose of suicide attacks on common people. Furthermore, Pashtun genocide in FATA is a selective operation. We must also consider Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the series of recent clashes in Karachi, and further rise of TTP there. Then there's the idea of Polio target as a western conspiracy. This is now the conservative wisdom from Pakistanis and others, as well.

This war seems to be never ending; sectarian clashes are on the rise. Today, if radicals are gaining strength, tomorrow, nationalists will be somehow fascists in second position. Even now, if Pakistan wishes to settle, gone are the days where this was possible. Now the region is declining steadily until such time as the USA desires to fulfill the targets they aimed for.

It is also another perception that the 'few figures' are yet encouraging owing to the concept of: ‘wait and see’ until the withdrawal of the Nato forces. These figures will then have to appear in their pivotal role in the share of Afghanistan's political transition considering security transition has already been accomplished. This again turns with dual policy. We cry for the violent loss of sovereignty (Drone Attacks) yet we are reluctant to act against those masterminds who tacitly insist the USA carry out ' More Strikes'. We fear the Indian influence in Afghanistan, yet we are reluctant to offer support to Afghanistan. If we really aspire to move towards peace in the country then we need to stand firmly with Afghanistan. For example, India is currently constructing dams, projects, and infrastructure: winning the hearts and minds of Afghan people. We need to take a similar stance in order to further deter the plight and ultimate possibility of 'Civil War.’ We further need to form a strategy to avoid internal collapse. Further implosion will alienate the people to extremes and may turn this One Nation Theory into far-sighted multiple Ethnic theories, in order to save their concerned areas from the dangerous influences of their cultural and religious agitators. Our mistakes are now bearing fruits, as international powers play the same game with us in keeping us busy, busy and busy.

item.title: “Non-Violence:” A Tool of Conflict Resolution
item.dc:creator: Syed Wasif Azim
item.content:encoded:
“Pacifism is necessarily revolutionary; we will not have peace unless there is a profound change in social structure.”(Paul Goodman, 1962)

 

Non- violence is a tool of conflict resolution which avoids as well as resolves conflict peacefully. Nonviolence is actually a way of life that seeks to win friendship and understanding, to defeat injustice, to educate and transform through voluntary suffering, by choosing love instead of hate, believing that the universe is on the side of justice.

 

Thomas A. Edison termed non-violence as a tool that leads to the highest ethics, the real goal of all evolution of humans, saying that until we stop harming all other living beings, we are still savages, faraway from Civilization. (Edison)

 

(1.2)Principle Steps of Non-violence:

 

•              Gather Information

•              Educate people

•              Remain Committed and stick to the task

•              Negotiate peacefully

•              Take an Action Peacefully

•              And Reconcile to a greater and maximum extent

 

These steps are utilized rather systematically in conflict resolution and have been very effective from a small societal level to higher National, and at times international level. However, the system involves some pre requirements, such as; courage, guidance, practice and a spiritual awareness.

 

Categories of Non- violence:

 

 Protest and persuasion: Protest and persuasion is a form and type or practice of Non- violence. It includes activities such as: speech-making, petitions, marches, rallies, vigils, and teach-ins. It must be considered that even the most temperate form of action may require great courage, yet can have a powerful impact, if practiced and followed in the right way. This methodology can be used to resolve issues, conflicts or to oppose government with positive results.

 

 ‘Non-cooperation’ is another form on non- violence. With regard to institutional injustice, people may refuse to act in ways which are considered normal everyday activities. Active non-cooperation is, and has been a very effective tool, which has been used throughout history. Examples such as the ‘civil disobedience campaign’ instigated by congress in India, was used as a means to compel British Colonial powers to submit to their demands.

 

This category of nonviolent action may include

 

•              Refusal to pay taxes

•              Withholding rent or utility payments

•              More than fifty different kinds of boycotts and strikes 

•              Civil disobedience

•              Fasting etc.

 

 Intervention:

 

The third type or category of non-violence is intervention, which can be defined as the active disruptive presence of people in the usual processes of social institutions. This is a more direct method and produces immediate challenges in effect.

 

Tactics of this category are

 

•              Sit-ins

•              Occupation

•              Obstructions of “business as usual” in offices and streets

•              The creation of new social and economic institution

•              The establishment of parallel governments which compete and stand against the old order

 

Martin Luther king honoured the philosophy of ‘love and non- violence,’ particularly while fighting for the rights of oppressed people. He further stated that more than anything else, he learned the method of social reform from this philosophy: “The intellectual and moral satisfaction which I could not acquire from Bentham and Mill, Marx and Lenin; from the optimism of Rousseau; from the superman philosophy of Nietzsche; from social-contracts theory of Hobbes: I acquired that from the philosophy of love and non- violence of Mahatma Gandhi. (King, 1958)

 

Indian Independence, Bacha Khan & Non-violence:

 

Indian independence didn’t come about in a matter of days or years but was made possible with great sacrifice: requiring time, establishment of movements, organizations, Ideologies and further contribution of leaders.  Social, political as well as educational movements paved the way to liberation.  The practice and success of non- violent methods adopted by Gandhi, in the pursuit of Indian independence, has inspired leaders such as Martin Luther King Jr. While resolving the African American population’s civil rights conflict in the United States of America in the 1960’s, he utilized the practice and methods of non- violence in order to create awareness and endeavour to achieve success, and as a result he was awarded the noble peace prize in 1964.

 

In India, non- violence was practiced by two Leaders: Gandhi and Bacha Khan. Bacha Khan instigated the non-violent movement in North West Frontier (Now Khyber Pukhtoonhwa) called the ‘Khudai Khidmatgar’ movement, aimed at resisting British colonial imperialism and Socio political reforms in this Pukhtoon region. The movement was in conjunction with the nationalist party known as the ‘All Indian National Congress’ and comprised of thousands of Pashtuns, mostly from rural areas. The ‘no arms policy’ was thus implemented: The core value of this movement was explicitly ‘non-violence.’ (Shruti, 2013a).

 

Bacha Khan formed a movement known as ‘The Servants of God,’ which aimed to serve HIS people. Most people attribute this concept to the idea of Gandhi je, but Bacha himself said that he was guided by the ways of the last Prophet Muhammad (S.W.A) and therefore, Gandhi made his ‘Peace Army’ after Bacha khan’s Red shirt army of GOD. However there is no doubting their close friendship and shared ideas and ideals. This close association earned Bacha khan the name: ‘Frontier Gandhi’ (Shruti, 2013 b).

 

 “Bacha Khan based his life and work on the profound principle of  non-violence, raising an  army  of  courageous  men  and  women  who  translated  it  into  action (each member of the ‘Khudai Khidmatgar’ accepted an oath of ‘non-violent action).  Had  his  example been better known,  the  world  might  come  to  recognize  that  the  highest  religious  values  of  Islam  are  deeply compatible with non-violence, having the power to resolve conflicts even when confronted with heavy odds.”(Easwaran, 1999)

 

The third movement in this list is the great ‘Quit India Movement’ of 1942. The movement was supported throughout by peaceful leaders and the masses in general. On 15 July 1942, (during a Press conference attended by foreign media after the working committee meeting of Congress in Wardha), Gandhi Ji, in reply to a question stated: The movement, (Quit India), “were it to be launched, would be a non- violent rebellion against the British power.” ­ Bacha khan and his red shirts also supported, and joined this movement.  Britain was further hit so hard by this movement that it soon decided to give India freedom and leave this land. Gandhi’s ability to give voice to the authentic spirit of the Indian masses was at peak during this movement like the previous ones and that’s why this ideology witnessed success.

 

Throughout history, non- violence has been very effective in solving conflict issues ranging from individual level to national and international level and it did so in the liberation movement of India. I would say that without this effective tool it may not have been possible to free India from British rule, or certainly, it would have taken a longer period of time. Without this ideal of ‘non-violence,’ perhaps the outcome would have been even more devastating.  

 

In Khyber Pukhtoonkhwa today, over two million courageous followers of Bacha khan are fighting the worst shapes of militant violence, including social and political instability. Pukhtoons are not only fighting this war against militancy and extremism for their own survival, but also for broader regional peace and global security. The Civil society, academia and political activists of the region along with the international community need to study and analyse the life and struggle of Bacha Khan: Both his example and philosophy could prove to be a powerful tool to defeat this curse and bring peace in the region.

item.title: The Khudai Khidmatgar Movement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Khudai Khidmatgar Movement of: Unity, Reform and Non-Violent Political Struggle.

  In light of the current state of unrest in Pashtun lands, where militant activity is rife, violent killing of innocents an everyday occurrence, trust in political leaders at an all- time low, conspiracy theories and insinuations of corruption the norm, it’s difficult to imagine that there was a time when thousands of Pashtun people united steadfast in a movement which advocated egalitarian social reform, unity and nonviolence as its principal ideology. The Khudai Khidmatgar (servants of God) movement was established in 1929 by Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan 1890-1988 (aka: Bacha Khan), a man whose unparalleled leadership, sacrifice, insight, humanity and courage, transcended all preconceptions of stereotyping, leading his people to a new level of thought and non-violent political action. At a time when British Colonial power had reached its zenith on the Indian Subcontinent, the British further sought to hermetically validate their empire by creating the geographical border known as the Durand Line in 1893. With growing fears of Russian interest and possible invasion, the British recognized the importance of controlling Pashtuns as the ‘vital gatekeepers of the Indian empire.’[1] While the border arbitrarily divided the Pashtun community, leaving some in Afghanistan and some in what was then called the North West Frontier Province,[2] Pashtuns nonetheless ‘paid little attention to the International boundary.’[3] The continuous trade, communication and interaction between Pashtuns on either side of the border caused tumultuous anxiety for the British leading to the creation of a ‘regime of control in the Frontier, which was substantially harsher than elsewhere in the Subcontinent.’[4] This ‘divide and conquer’ policy was accompanied by the heavy administering of oppressive militarisation, crippling high taxation, poor sanitation and  little or no educational facilities. This was the historical, socio-political backdrop in which Bacha Khan (aged 20), set about travelling around the Province trying to convince, mostly illiterate locals, of the values of education. Having managed to open many schools, with the help of the Haji of Turangzai, a religious leader, he was nonetheless arrested by the authorities and the schools were closed down.  Bacha Khan further became involved in nationalist politics, through participation in the Muslim Khilafat protests opposing British rule, leading to the hijrat of 1920 to Afghanistan in which he was further detained and imprisoned on return to the Frontier. Once freed, Bacha Khan decided to go back to his village (Utmanzai) and adopt the path of non-violence.[5] While the hijrat confirmed the unreliability of religious leadership in the political sphere, it further convinced Bacha Khan that in order to achieve sustained solidarity, dedication, and unity of Pashtuns, he would need to create a new ideology, readdress Pashtun traditional social practices, particularly Pakhtunwali (code of honour) and communicate with his people at grassroots level. In 1921, with the help of members of Pashtun intelligentsia and small Khans, Bacha Khan launched the Anjuman I Islah ul Afghina (Society for the Reform of Afghans). Their plan of social reform involved touring villages in Settled Districts, discussing the importance of education, the beauty of the Pashto language and poetry, urging the need to refrain from feuding and discord. Gradually, many schools were established in various areas.  As well as seeing this as a means of empowering Pashtuns, he viewed education as the greatest tool to opposing British rule. Eventually up to 70 schools were established and hundreds of children were learning Pashto, Mathematics, history, Qur’an, Hadith and various vocational skills.[6] In launching the Khudai Khidmatgar movement, Bacha Khan travelled (sometimes by bicycle, often on foot), to hundreds of villages in an effort to convince people how the movement of social reform would secure improved living conditions and political freedom for Pashtuns. He began by setting up a network of training camps where volunteers would undergo physical training, he urged people to clean their villages and improve sanitation. Another innovation was the idea of a uniform, where members dipped their clothes in dye, thus acquiring the popular name of ‘Red Shirts.’[7] In 1929, at an All Indian National Congress conference, Jawarhalala Nehru launched a mass campaign of civil disobedience in an effort to gain complete independence for India. Being a member of the Frontier Congress, Bacha Khan pledged his alliance to the campaign, advising Pashtuns not to pay taxes or rent, he further stated that any villagers working for the state as collectors should resign or be socially boycotted.[8] The significant event which propelled the Khudai Khidmatgar organization into political action with conviction was the Kissa Khani Bazaar massacre of 23rd April 1930. Congress delegates were due to arrive from Delhi to investigate Frontier Crimes Regulation and other repressive measures.[9] Hundreds of civilians including many hundred Red Shirts gathered at Peshawar station to meet the delegation, but were instead informed that the committee had been refused entry to the Province. Having again arrested Bacha Khan, mayhem thus ensued, with troops opening fire on the crowd, killing 200 people. The stance of non-violence, on the part of the KK, in light of extreme provocation, was clear indication of their commitment to a non-violent ideology, and consequently provided substantial evidence of the different standards of political repression in the Frontier compared to the rest of India. The massacre further increased Congress interest in the Khudai Khidmatgar movement, offering financial and technical support. In gaining momentum, and further increase in membership, the KK movement proved a major obstacle for the British, who in turn adopted more lethal methods of oppression, by burning homes, looting property and incarcerating Khudai Khidmatgar sympathisers. Bacha Khan’s approach of leadership did not employ elusive and distant bureaucratic control measures. His methodology was to address his people personally, touring villages delivering hundreds of speeches: drawing attention to the unjust policy of British rule. In an incredible feat of ingenuity Bacha Khan reconciled Pashtuns to the concept of non-violent measure at all costs. This concept was contrary to the traditional Pashtun code of honour which approved of reciprocal revenge for any misdeed or insult.  In order to achieve unity each member would have to set aside their traditional differences; practice self-restraint and forego all violent and aggressive behaviour. Bacha Khan argued ‘how can a man be truly honourable when he had allowed the British to insult Islam and reduced women and children to wear rags?’[10] Equally remarkable, having regard to the inflexible observance of purdah, is the fact that Bacha Khan encouraged education for women, further suggesting they join the nationalist struggle to assist their men in civil disobedience.[11] Throughout the 17 years of the Khudai Khidmatgar movement, brutal measures were employed by the authorities causing enormous suffering and loss of life. In 1932, during a demonstration at Kohat, the British opened fire killing three hundred Khudai Khidmatgar members and injuring thousands more after the arrest of Bacha Khan. Techniques of cruelty such as physical beatings and shootings regularly took place in prisons; Bacha Khan himself was incarcerated on several occasions and spent much of his life in prison. When the partition of 1947 was announced it came as a major blow to Bacha Khan and his brother Dr. Khan Saheb, who was then congress chief minister in the Province. Bacha Khan had always supported congress in combined effort to combat British Rule. Partition would place Pashtuns at the mercy of the Muslim league, which Bacha Khan had strongly opposed. Nevertheless, Congress decided to come to terms with the Muslim league and partition was agreed without consultation with the Frontier and its Leaders. Bacha Khan considered this an act of treachery, telling Ghandi: ‘you have thrown us to the wolves.[12] Bacha Khan and the Frontier congress further demanded a free state of Pashtunistan, with a constitution based on the Islamic concept of democracy, equality and social justice. He argued that Pashtuns had their own distinct history and culture and this could not be preserved unless they had full freedom to maintain and develop their own institutions. However neither Jinnah nor Mountbatten agreed. The result favoured the Muslim League and the British Government accepted it. Furthermore, the new found government of the frontier opposed reconciliation between Jinnah and the Khan Brothers; and incarcerated all KK leaders and its members without any legal charge or trial.[13]  Bacha Khan was further detained in Pakistani prisons for many years during the post-partition phase. However, his legacy, achievement and struggle were not in vain. The Khudai Khidmatgar movement revolutionised Pashtun culture, society and politics by strategic non-violent oppositional measures, radical reforms, and redefining traditional sociological structures and customs. The organizational structures put in place by Bacha Khan were essential to the endurance of the KK movement. As an inspired leader, Bacha Khan managed to raise Pashtun national pride by instilling a sense of autonomy and by preserving culture amongst Pashtun people. Under his charismatic supreme leadership, thousands of Pashtuns practiced self-restraint and non-violence, through ‘a creative ideological position that was grounded in Islam and Pashtun Custom.[14] His legacy lives on in the hearts and minds of millions of Pashtuns today.  

[1] Banerjee, Mudulika. The Pathan Unarmed, Oxford University Press: Karachi & New Delhi, 2000, p.42.
[2] Modern day Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
[3] Spain, James W. The Way of The Pathans, Oxford University Press, 1962, p.22.
[4] Banerjee, p.42.

[12] Maulana Abdul Kalam Azad, India Wins Freedom, Orient Blackswan, 1984, p.210.
[13] Ibid., p.213-214.
[14] Banerjee, p. 209.

item.title: Afghan Pashtuns in Cork City Ireland
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Cork City is home to over 5,000 Muslims many of whom arrived here during the economic  boom, also known as the ‘Celtic Tiger,’ which witnessed a throng of immigrants from all parts of the world in the hope of carving out a new life, better living conditions, employment and education. Whilst the economy thrived for some time, the crash which led to the current economic crisis arrived hastily, but not without prior warning, inevitably falling on ‘deaf ears’ of the then government. The ‘Celtic Tiger’ also witnessed the arrival of many asylum seekers to Ireland, whose plans of a better future also rebounded as a result. While I was aware of the presence of a minority group of Pashtun people in Cork, some of whom I am in regular contact, I recently learned about a community of  Afghan Pashtun men, supposedly residing ‘somewhere’ in the City. The Asylum Seekers centres in Ireland are run by the Department of Justice and as a result are not easily accessible. The first centre I approached in fact, I was told in no uncertain terms that visitors are not allowed entry without permission from the necessary authorities, even though I produced my papers from my university stating my ‘fieldwork’ mission. After much conversation and ‘heart rendering’ stories on my part, the security guard finally succumbed and told me the whereabouts of the Afghan Pashtuns. Sometimes in life, one has to adopt a ‘brazen’ approach especially when confronted with bureaucratic mind-sets and administrative agents vehemently dismissing and purging their way through their perceived idea of the ‘misguided, ill-informed’ public! Determined to speak to the Afghan Pashtun community, I put aside all ideas of failure and boldly walked into the ‘Asylum Seekers’ accommodation centre in Cork City. It was only by the grace of God that the first man I met was from Peshawar. Stunned and amused at my good luck, I told him about my fieldwork mission and asked if there was the possibility of meeting with other Pashtun people. He seemed wary and suspicious of my purpose, so I produced my university ID. Having convinced him that my intentions were genuine, we further discussed Bacha Khan, the Pakhtu language and other related issues. Suddenly he was assured! He told me to come back at 5pm that evening. Meeting the Afghan Pashtuns was like meeting family members. In true Pashtun custom, ‘melmestia’ was in full swing!:  Afghan green tea waiting for me, and we sat together, six Afghan Pashtun men and myself, talking about Pashtun customs and traditions as if we had known each other for years. The first item in the room that I noticed was the Afghan flag, proudly draped across the wall…..It was a symbolic reminder for me that even though I live a world away from the culture that I love, in some small capacity, it had come to me, here in Ireland.

The following is an account of our conversation.

1)            How long have you guys been in Ireland?  “Some of us have been here for four years and most of us almost seven years.”

2)            Why did you choose Ireland?  "It is an English speaking country and a safe country. We could have gone to France or Scandinavia, but we heard through other Afghans that Ireland was a good destination."

3)            How difficult was it to get a visa to Ireland and did it cost much money to leave Afghanistan? "Yes it cost too much money. But at that time, it wasn’t difficult to get into Ireland. Now it is almost impossible for immigrants to get into this country."

4)            What do you guys do all day? "Very little, we eat breakfast, spend a lot of time on the internet, go into the city, walk around, but mostly spend time here together with friends."

5)            How much money do you receive from the State?  "19 euros per week. So our lives are really boring here, because we don’t have money to do anything. Everything costs money and Ireland is expensive. We are mostly bored because we have been waiting years for the papers for the Irish ‘green card’ so we have no idea how much longer we will have to wait. Some of us share rooms with other people we don’t know. Some of the rooms have 4 beds. It’s like an open prison here. We go to bed really late and get up the second we awaken so that we don’t have to spend time with the people we are sharing with. We just all meet in this room. All the Afghan people."

6)            Are there any children living in this house, and have you come across asylum seekers who are here with families back home?  "There are no children in this accommodation, mostly single men. The other centre on the airport road, that is where all the families are housed. Yes, we know some men , Afghan men who are here as asylum seekers and their wives and kids are home in Afghanistan. It’s really difficult for them."

7)            Tell me about the process of applying for asylum in Ireland: "When you arrive, you fill out the forms etc., then there is a second meeting with a judge who decides if you can stay. But many of us found that our original statements to the police were altered. For example when I (most talkative man in the room) was brought before the judge and my statement was read out, there was incorrect information and I told them that I never said that. But because it was on the original statement, it was processed anyway. We have witnessed many people coming here to Ireland who receive their green card and papers within 15 days or one month. It’s really unfair."

8)            Why has this happened, how did they manage to do that?  "Because these are usually wealthy people who are highly educated and know the law before even coming to the country. They know how to work the law, what to say, what to write and how to fix things so that they get permits straight away."

9)            What was your situation in this regard. Did you not research a little before coming here? "No, our English was not good then, and we wanted to leave Afghanistan in a big hurry, so we just got a flight to Ireland in a hurry. Our country is in a very difficult position. There are wars, fighting, killings every day. It is getting worse."

10)          What do you think of Ireland and Irish people?  (smiles, looking at each other etc..): Me: Come on guys, you can be open with me. Don’t feel you have to pretend to like it here if you don’t: (reply): "Well the best thing about Ireland is that it’s safe. You can live freely, walk down the street, talk to people, it’s very relaxed here and there are no big worries such as fearing for your life or being stopped by police all the time."

11)          Have you ever witnessed racist remarks or actions here? "Nothing big, but occasionally some remarks can be made."

12)          Such as? Are they offensive?  "Now and then, but you have no choice but to just ignore them and keep walking or doing what you’re doing."

13)          How about Language. Do any of you attend schools/courses etc.,?  "There is a school but the teachers there are so dumb. They are teaching words that you would teach children like dog, cat, door etc., and they never seem to move on from this. Every time we went there the classes were at the same level…for beginners. Its really stupid. We learn from talking to people, from meeting people here in the house. Irish people, like the chef and delivery people. That English school is a joke."

14)          So can you leave this country now and go home or go anywhere else? "No we are prisoners until we get our papers and permit. Once we get that, then we can work, or leave the country. If we left now, due to fingerprinting, the country that we will arrive in will just send us back to Ireland. We have no choice now but to stay here until we get our papers. We didn’t think it would take so long. I mean, being here locked up like this for seven years is so depressing. And with no money, we can’t get involved in activities. Also, without our papers/permit, we are not allowed to work. So we can’t work or earn a living. It is hopeless."

15)          What is this accommodation like. What’s the food like?  "As you can see, we are locked up together in these small rooms. Its ok here. The food is just ok."

16)          Is there ‘halal’ food choice here? "Well they write up on the notice board what’s on the menu in all the different languages. We don’t know if it’s halal or haram."

17)          This Green tea is really nice. I have been looking for Afghan tea since I came back from Pakistan and I can’t find any in Cork. Where did you get this?  "There is a Pakistani shop on Shandon street. They have it imported from Pakistan."

18)          So I take it you guys don’t drink alcohol. What do you think of the Irish pub culture. Do you ever visit pubs or clubs?  "Once per year we all go out together. No we don’t drink alcohol, but we like visiting the pubs. It’s a good atmosphere."

19)          I have many more questions that I would like to ask you. Would it be possible for me to meet here with you again?  "Yes, absolutely. We love to have guests. You can visit any time or day you like."

20)          How about next Tuesday at the same time….5pm?  "Yes, great. See you then."

And so ended my first meeting with Afghan Pashtun People in Cork. Watch this space, as we have planned to carry out further meetings, including Pashtu language learning. Happy Days!
