item.title: Call for Avoiding ‘Duel Role’
item.dc:creator: AD Babar
item.content:encoded:
T.S Eliot once upon said “Has the Church failed mankind; or has mankind failed the Church”.

It seems that a similar question could be asked in relation to Muslims living in some Countries. For instance Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Egypt, and Libya and to some extent Pakistan: have all been fighting a war with apparently invisible terrorists or militants. One could ask has the Mosque failed the Muslims or have Muslims failed the Mosque? As a result, a common Muslim feels hesitant to call himself Muslim; particularly after the emergence of terrorism in the aforesaid countries. As if that’s not enough, the menace of terrorism is scourging every corner of Asia, from Peshawar to Paris, Middle Eastern countries to the West. All this apparently gives rise to the notion that terrorism is not the failure of any State; rather it makes an impressive feature of states for the sake of affluence. In this regard, foreign policy is one of the main input sources that can play a vital role in countering terrorism in each country. Formation and implementation of the said policy is essentially subjected to the U.N charter. U.N Security Organization suggestions for such Countries needs to be applied. It includes that a state enjoys the rights to protect its   geographical location, sovereignty, territory, historical legacy. To expand an accurate response, it becomes mandatory to sincerely analyze and address the principal causes of ‘Islamic militancy’ which is no longer an individual threat for a state .The fear is that if it is cropping up at such an alarming scale,  It will inevitably affect many other countries of the world. The origin of Islamic militancy can be traced back to the failure of Muslim countries whereby the majority population struggles to survive atrocious socio-economic conditions, poverty, and in many cases, people can barely afford to put food on the table. Justice is painstakingly awaited and the growing population of youth is inclined to experience loss of self-esteem and dignity. This vacuum is, straightforwardly, filled by the Zombie movement i.e. AQL, ISIL, ISIS and TTP, in the East, and by the Al Qaeda collaboration on the part of Pakistan…. in the subsequent systematic carving up of humanity. This phenomenon could be furthermore perceived as a repetition of history similar to the British strategy in the 40s, using the posture of criminal enterprise for expansionism.  In other words, it is like ‘old wine in a new bottle.’ The policies run by the USA, with its tacit designs, reveal startling new techniques, one recent report, (bearing in mind we cannot believe everything we read), nonetheless suggests that the IS operation has gained funds from the USA. The terrorist outfits have gone far beyond winning hearts and minds of as many Muslims as possible, not to mention territories. This approach automatically plays into the hands of these ideologically driven terrorists. Various stories of heinous crimes have dominated the media such as the execution of over 150 women and girls in Fallujah for refusing to marry their men, according to Iraqi Human Rights Ministry. Rape of a journalist and cutting her breast have been reported in Libya…another example of the barbaric acts which cannot be explained in plain words. There are many more mind-boggling shocking incidents which are beyond the scope of this article to relay. Imagine, for a moment, if the same phenomenon comes to Pakistan it would add more heinous unparalleled crimes to the existing atrocities. Recruitment of the ISIS is growing day by day and approaching its sub-nexus to Pakistan. It also cannot be ignored that some of the Muslim countries have reportedly been involved in funding these militants. Also, it is not deniable that the countries maintain the policies exploited with the same prototype of stygian mess as exploited in the past by dominating countries. Still reaction of the superpower against eliminating terrorism is run with double standards i.e. at one location Al-Qaeda or other outfits are targeted while on the other hand, other places are left for further exploitation of the masses in their hands, another example would be the stance on freedom of speech in the wave of the Paris attack. So, the Muslim countries also learnt the same design deceiving its own masses for the vested interests running the state, by few, within the domain. The rise of the radical Islamist movement is unfalteringly running and fitful. The US, to its credit, seems to be doing nothing as its interests are completed on the part of Afghanistan and partially in Pakistan. 70 % tolerant Pakistanis saw the identical rise of outlawed parties propagating a narrow and exclusivist version of Islam. The country has been hesitant in eliminating this as a whole, instead it turned more sophisticated in tackling these issues. It is worth mentioning that a major turning point was the use of Islamist zealots to combat the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and these rudiments were created with USA collaboration and funds. With it, now Pakistan is digging its own grave. A mere apparent session of press releases and official statements with embellished photos do not achieve anything: Addressing ‘Islamic terrorism’ is now a global challenge and therefore must become a priority. The US, leading State of the nations at war, yes war, not a simple war, but the war that will define the fate of global peace, particularly Pakistan and the Muslim world, is unavoidably in dire need to be negotiated through sincere analysis. Otherwise, it will fix or reseat the ideological setup and exorcise the demon we have been nurturing in the world for decades.  Also, ‘self-defense’ and the concept of ‘doing more’ have to be reviewed and peaceful alternatives have to be searched for through political means. In this regard, Pakistan needs the same practice of politics now and in the future. According to Newton’s Law, every action has its reaction. The people of war-hit countries are unequivocally fed up of war. Islamic militancy and terrorism have claimed thousands of lives of innocent citizens. For Pakistan, it is high time to settle the dispute without wasting more energy on useless formulas against terrorism. The majority of Muslim do not love or condone the activities of terrorists. But they can react by avoiding fundamental ideologies which are perishing human beings.

item.title: Children of the FATA: Heirs of Colonial Legacy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The on-going suffering of the people of FATA seems never ending. The injustice and discriminatory ill-treatment served upon these people by past and present governments, religious militants along with the actions of military authorities of Pakistan have led to a relentless onslaught of misery, hardship and impoverished living conditions in this region. Continued imposition of a set of draconian laws designed by British colonial administrations, in place since 1901, not only serve to keep the region locked in a time warp, but deny the people of FATA equal citizenship in effect. Extreme poverty, poor infrastructure, high illiteracy, unemployment, lack of education and health facilities, underpin the economically under-developed region as well as marginalize and reduce its people to near destitution. The geographic location of the FATA, considered significant from a strategic standpoint along with continued implementation of the arbitrary draconian regulations known as the Frontier Crimes Regulations (FCR) have been the root cause of untold miseries in the FATA. The colonial encounter with the FATA is traced back to 1849, when the Punjab was formally annexed by the British administration. The aggressive policy known as 'forward policy' was introduced due to fears of Russian expansion in Central Asia, and 'their rapid advancement towards Afghanistan' (Shah, 2012:4). In order to hermetically validate their empire, the British colonizers created the geographical border known as the Durand Line in 1893, which arbitrarily divided the Pashtun community, leaving some in Afghanistan and some in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (known as 'North West Frontier Province' at that time). The FATA, as a result, assumed the status of 'buffer zone' between Afghanistan and British India, and has since been maintained as such by subsequent actors and governments. In an attempt to formulate laws befitting what they understood to be analogous with Pashtun tradition and social organization, the British conjured and established a set of laws (FCR) which enforced the authority of a political agent and their assistant arbitrators, and middle men, the local chiefs (Maliks). The Maliks act as intermediaries between tribes and authorities in order to administer government policy. 'The political officer was essentially the go-between of his day, functioning as a conduit for the two-way flow of information between the government and the inhabitants of the tribal areas.' (Tripodi,2008:126). Shah states 'the political agents are given huge funds, not auditable since colonial days, to use at his own discretion, and a major share of these funds go to the tribal maliks. The leading maliks were selected by him (PA) and graded according to the importance of their tribe'(Shah, 2012:3). In addition to the FCR regulations, article 247 of the constitution poses a major stumbling block as it places a bar on parliamentarians to legislate for the tribal areas of Pakistan, therefore none of the Acts of Parliament are enforcible in the FATA. see http://fatareforms.org/2014/05/07/article-247/ Furthermore, the colonial legislation, which is inherently oppressive, cultivates the continuation of human rights violations in many areas. 'After the departure of the British from South Asia, (1947), the Pakistan government endorsed all old treaties and pacts signed with the tribesmen and ensured they should enjoy the same facilities granted to them by the British authorities' (Shah, 2012:3). Moving forward to the 1980's, the FATA witnessed the rise of militancy when it was 'used as a base from which to wage the mujahideen war against the Soviet Union in Afghanistan' (Ijaz Khan:2014). The withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan (1989) witnessed the launch of the taliban regime (1996), eventually overthrown by American and NATO troops in the wake of 9/11 attacks. It is widely known that as a result, many members of the taliban absconded and relocated to the tribal areas of Pakistan from where they continued to plot and launch attacks. Furthermore, Ijaz Khan states: 'any agreements reached between religious militants /insurgents and the Pakistani government have failed, resulting in the expansion of the militants' territorial control. There has thus emerged a continuous pattern of state erosion and growing militant influence spreading out of the Fata into the settled districts of KPK' (Ijaz Khan: 2014). The recent (June 2014) 'Zarb-e-Azb' operation by the Pakistani military/government was launched in an effort to flush out all foreign and local militant groups hiding in North Waziristan. The campaign furthermore received widespread support from the US as well as the Pakistani political, defence and civilian sectors. However, it was the tribal people who paid the price, some with their lives, which involved the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of families from their homes at short notice, additionally forced to endure and suffer diabolical conditions at 'displaced peoples' camps, while others fared better in finding temporary accommodation provided by Pashtun families in the settled areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. After many months, the long awaited government (military) announcement (March 2015) arrived stating the 'successful' operation was complete, and displaced people could now return safely to their homes. However, much to the horror of the people of Waziristan, the return home for these long suffering people would come with a harsh price tag: permission to repatriate would depend upon the signing of a 'social agreement.' This despicable precondition can only be described as blackmail styled tactics and a further attempt by the Pakistani authorities to keep the tribal people in a constant state of oppression, through the reinforcement of a severe colonial law system which in effect condemns the people to a life of misery with little rights and zero autonomy . The social agreement 'calls for the residents to swear loyalty to the Frontier Crimes Regulation, thus barring them from ever being able to object to an unjust colonial law that denies them full citizenship. Further, the agreement stipulates harsh collective punishments for entire tribes in case of infringement of the agreement by individuals members' (Aasim Sajjad Akhtar, AWP Statement: 2015). Another ludicrous stipulation is that the tribes are “collectively and individually” responsible for any breach of peace emanating from the return of militancy. The agreement therefore puts the onus of securing North Waziristan on the tribal people, absolving the state of responsibility.' (Ibid). Is it not the duty of State to provide safety and security to its citizens? Being allowed to return to their homes on the condition that they fight militants and maintain the peace is senseless, as the agreement also states that the people must give up the arms they will need for defending themselves against the Taliban. This mind-boggling idea and approach by the government (military) not only demonstrates failure to protect or even show any semblance of concern for citizens, but furthermore proves the incompetence of the government in finding solutions to this ongoing detrimental and life threatening situation in the FATA. The (supposed) clearance of militants from the tribal areas would have been the ideal opportunity for the government to implement reforms and abolish the FCR for once and for all, but alas, once more, another opportunity has slipped away, I would dare to say not unwittingly!   Watch; http://fatareforms.org/2015/03/31/struggle-for-equal-rights-in-fata-video/   Works cited: Aasim Sajjad Akhtar, AWP Statement: 2015 https://www.facebook.com/AwamiWorkersParty?fref=ts Christian Tripodi. 'Peacemaking through bribes or cultural empathy? The political officer and Britain's strategy towards the North-West Frontier, 1901-1945,' Journal of Strategic Studies, 2008. Ijaz Khan. 'Challenges facing development in Pakistan tribal areas ' http://www.fatareforms.org/challenges-facing-development-fata-pakistan-dr-ijaz-khan/ Syed Wiqar Ali Shah, 'Political Reforms in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas of Pakistan (FATA): Will it End the Current Militancy? Heidelberg Papers in Sount Asian and Comparative Politics, 2012. http://fatareforms.org/

item.title: Observations on Father/Son Relationship in Pashtun Society
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In Pashtun society males dominate the domestic, social, and political sphere. Within the family nucleus, the father/husband has all authority. He controls the social interactions of family members, along with property. He may use physical compulsion to enforce his authority and he alone has the right to dissolve the domestic unit or expel its members by divorce or by disinheriting the children.[1] Barth states ‘patrilineal descent receives considerable emphasis among Pashtuns, forming an ideology of respect for father and father’s father, and solidarity between brothers. A father’s authority is recognized throughout his life and a strong tie of affection and loyalty is always assumed.’[2]  Edwards writes:

In Pashtun society a man without a father has no identity. As long as the father is alive, the son will always be subordinate. Detachment from ones father means that one is alienated from the honour which the father represents and from the community of individuals bound by their shared concern for honour.[3]

Pashtun males are brought up in the knowledge that the father (male elder) commands absolute authority and control over  every aspect of socio-economic, political and to a great extent domestic life, leading to subordinate roles on the part of sons. Pierre Bourdieu speaks of ‘symbolic violence’ as being ‘imperceptible and invisible to its victims,’[4]  whereby this ‘gentle violence is exerted through channels of communication, cognition, recognition and even feeling.’[5] I argue here that societal demands and expectations propagate the continuous upholding of the institutions of Paktunwali, maintained under the direction of male elders, thus a ‘symbolic violence’ manifests through channels of communication, particularly through the assumed supreme authority of the father figure. As a result, male Pashtuns are consistently discouraged from deviating from prescribed social norms. The relationship between father and son then is understood and contrived in a way which reduces the possibility of personal autonomy, further imposing a dependence upon and subordination to the father figure.

 I find it useful here to further analyse the father and son relationship in a quest to understand to what extent it affects and generates the culture of male honour. Bourdieu states ‘men constitute a political and symbolic strength without which the group cannot protect and expand its patrimony.’[6] In the patrilineal system of Pashtuns, the fathering of male heirs is prioritized in order to promulgate what Bourdieu terms the ‘political and symbolic’ strength of the group, for it is through sons that Pashtun society maintains its patriarchal, male dominant social order. The manner, in which boys are raised then, constitutes an important part of this discussion.  Lindholm recounts ‘the way children are raised, as theorists tirelessly pointed out, deeply indoctrinates them in the social order, and thus is the mechanism through which the culture reproduces itself.’[7]  He further states:

Boys are raised to present themselves as paragons of Pashtun virtue in Public. They have been taught that they deserve to be served the best of everything on demand. The child is allowed any permissible behaviour to escape public shaming, which occurs when one is shown not to live up to the ideals of strength, pride and self-reliance. The attitude of a Pashtun man is formed by a childhood made up of pampering and arbitrary violence and expectations that he present a manly public face combined with a constant fear of humiliation.[8]

Pashtun males are raised with the expectation that they will abide by the practice of idealistic behavioural norms, which altogether embody the perceived ideal of ‘honour,’ and to further shun public humiliation and shame at all cost. Bearing these factors in mind, I now endeavour to question the adult male/father relationship.

The father (male elder) and son relationship becomes more complex as the child grows up. Land and personal identity are deeply entwined in Pashtun thought and ‘a man is not truly Pashtun until he has absolute control of property.’[9] This factor can lead to violence, disputes and resentment between fathers and sons. ‘The tendency of old men to hold on to their land as long as possible is a major source of the pervasive tension between fathers and sons.’[10]

These factors therefore present a problematic, paradoxical situation for Pashtun males. Males are brought up in such a way as to feel superior. In public they are expected to display pride, honour and self- reliance in order to resist humiliation, yet they are always subordinate to the father as long as he is alive.  The father, during his lifetime, also has the power to disinherit his son, should an unfavourable situation or dispute arise between them.  To be disinherited or ostracized in Pashtun society brings dishonour and shame to the parties involved, leading to the likelihood that proposals and decisions, orchestrated by the father, will be adhered to.

Bourdieu states that ‘every man has to rise to his own childhood conception of manhood.’[11]  In Pashtun society, land[12] and personal identity are of paramount importance, yet if the father is not willing to give his son a share of land before his death, this further dispels any chance of personal autonomy. In order then, to maintain his own honour and that of the family and tribe, a son must align with the father’s decisions, as the father commands absolute authority on all matters. Yet as Edwards states ‘the ultimate objective of the man of honour is to exhibit independence in his actions and to sustain the appearance that he is not dependent upon or determined by any other individual.’[13] Of course the majority of these cases concerning land issues are particular to rural areas. In most urban areas of Pashtun regions today, the vast majority of men gain university degrees and become financially independent. Nonetheless, the general consensus seems to point to the fact that sons continue to be subordinate to and under the watchful gaze of the father in a society organized on the basis of kinship where maintaining honour is of paramount importance.

item.title: Observations on Honour, Masculinity and Seclusion of Women in Pashtun Society
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Pashtun society ‘is organized on the basis of kinship. Strictly patrilineal, the fundamental concept of the society is that all those related through a common male ancestor stand united against outsiders.’[1] Therefore ‘those who share an ancestor are obliged by the tie of blood to defend one another against outsiders.’[2]  Pashtun society then is a male dominated patriarchal society, in which the family and close blood ties play a primary role as the binding force, of which honour and a united stance are key players. In Masculinity and Power, Britten defines Patriarchy as ‘the male perception of a biological fact, which is translated into the basic principle of social organization.’[3]  He further asserts: ‘to be masculine requires self-reliance, self- control and control over other people and resources.’[4] This theory aligns with the fundamental ideals of pukhtunwali which presupposes and identifies men as having absolute authority and control over domestic, social and political life, consequently demanding an interminable demonstration of ‘masculinity.’ I find what Foucault termed ‘the society of normalisation,’[5]  consistent with my understanding of how ‘power’ dynamics have developed and become ‘normalised’ in Pashtun society. Foucault considers each society as ‘having its regime and general politics of truth: the types of discourse which it accepts and makes function as true.’[6] The institutions of pakhtunwali are traditions that have been taught, accepted and practiced throughout generations, thus leading to what Foucault terms a ‘society of normalisation.’ Foucault understands ‘power’ as being ‘exercised rather than possessed,’[7] developing as an invisible, autonomous phenomenon, strengthening and increasing throughout the social body, eventually leading to normalisation. The patriarchal, male dominant Pashtun society then, sustains its power through the exercising and implementation of traditional customs and values which are both the driving force and symbolically accepted ‘norms’ of the social organization.   I shall now explore the concept and theory of ‘masculinity’ and ‘power.’ Bourdieu writes ‘the social order functions as an immense symbolic machine tending to ratify the masculine domination on which it is founded. The strength of the masculine order is seen in the fact that it dispenses with justification.’[8] I find this theory poignantly addresses the ideological and structurally maintained order, which assumes and accepts male dominance as justifiably ‘the norm,’ within the strictly patrilineal Pashtun organization.  It is accepted and expected of males to command authority and dominance by displaying and imposing their ‘masculinity and power’ over every aspect of domestic, social and political life. Britten recounts: ‘masculinism is the ideology that justifies and naturalizes male domination, and as such it is the ideology of patriarchy. It sanctions the political and dominant role of men in the public and private spheres.’[9] According to the institutions of Pakhtunwali with its central theme of honour, ‘masculinity’ is thus demonstrated through the establishment of male dominance, whether exercised through defence of home and land, or the closely guarding and controlling of women: the primary motivation is to maintain respect and an ‘honourable’ position in society. The role of masculinity and power is also played out in the public political sphere as Barth found:   The elementary corporate units in the political system are all based on the principle of individual captaincy. There is thus a leader for each group; and the sources of his authority derive from the whole range of his relations to his followers. Pride, rivalry and virility is expected of chiefs: such behaviour is encouraged and admired.[10]   Therefore, it is not just in the domestic and social sphere that Pashtun men are urged and expected to exude and display characteristics of masculinity such as pride, honour and virility, but also in the political sphere where an authoritarian stance is further encouraged and valued. I now endeavour to analyse to what extent these factors affect and concern women, and particularly how the role of women is perceived within the ideal of upholding male honour. Britten states ‘masculinity does not exist in isolation from femininity – it will always be an expression of the current image that men have of themselves in relation to women.’[11]  Discussing the seclusion and protection of women (namus &purdah) Barth recounts: ‘seclusion establishes an organization of activities which allows emphasis on virility and the primacy of male society thus preventing the realities of performance in domestic life from affecting a man’s public image.’[12] He goes on to make a very important observation, that ‘a male is dependent on and vulnerable through his women.’[13]   The central concepts of pakhtunwali are dignity, honour and shame. Glatzer writes ‘to be called “shameless” is the worst possible insult and a deadly threat to the social position of the insulted.’[14] A Landinfo report states:   Women cannot increase the honour of a family or group; in reality they can only contribute to reducing it. The behaviour of women influences the family status and that of male relatives. Women are required to be modest and respectable and men are responsible for their behaviour and have an absolute obligation to protect them.[15]   In light of this jealous guarding and seclusion of women, to what extent do women have the ability and wherewithal to challenge male honour? Barfield states ‘any attack on a woman, physical or verbal is seen as an attack on a man’s honour and must be revenged. Similarly, any sexual improprieties by women themselves are violations of the honour code and may lead to the killing of that woman by male relatives.’[16]  However, women ‘play a large role in accessing men’s honour. It is women’s opinion that is often decisive in raising and lowering a man’s position. Their praise or malicious gossip can have a powerful impact on how a man is judged.’[17] Edwards asserts that ‘the man of honour must become dependent on women, although categorically inferior to him, are capable of denying him social respect.’[18] He further argues that women are in the privileged position of witnessing and reporting on all aspects of male activity, including commenting on their husband’s sexual prowess. Men of the household as well as male in-laws are always under the gaze of women, and as a result, capable of shaming men through verbal indiscretion.[19] The institution of namus and purdah then, dictates that men are responsible for the guarding and seclusion of women, implemented through severely imposed restrictions on the activities and behaviour of women. While this institution could be seen as a controlling agent in the hands of men, women are nonetheless perceived as having the power and wherewithal to shame men, through verbal indiscretion such as commenting and reporting on male activity and performance. The ‘shaming power’ of women then is greatly feared among Pashtun men as it can affect the public image, social standing, respect and honour of men.   This perceived ‘threat’ to male honour can also be observed in relation to the institution of Badal, meaning “exchange,” although fundamentally understood as ‘revenge’ whereby retribution is sought at all cost for any slight, insult or injury. Blood feud perpetrated in retaliation of insult, injury or death of loved ones, has been found in other pre-modern societies and persists in other places around the world. In such societies, revenge is not merely an option but a duty.[20] In Nisbett & Cohen[21] an extensive study carried out amongst Southern (American) white males, found norms characteristic of a “culture of honour.” The findings highlighted ‘the insult-aggression cycle in a culture in which insults diminish a man’s reputation and he tries to restore his status by aggressive or violent behaviour.’[22]  Spierenburg also recounts how violence and honour have played a prominent role in male cultures. In these societies, honour, shame and a person’s reputation often depend on physical bravery and a forceful response to insults.[23] In Pashtun society, Lutz states:   …if a bad deed consists in an attack on a person’s honour or integrity, reciprocation therefore means to take revenge. Revenge is aimed at restoring the primary balance between the individuals and groups and retrieving one’s honour. For example, killing a person often requires killing the killer or one of his relatives.[24]    Syed Bahodine Majrouh recounts, if a Pashtun man is involved in armed conflict, it is his duty to face the enemy, until death if need be, otherwise he will be ridiculed and branded a coward by all the women of his tribe.[25] Majrouh further explains: if a Pashtun man returns from a battle, he will ‘inevitably wonder what the village women will say. If he comes back humiliated or beaten, without having killed his rival, it will be impossible for him to live honourably in his home.’[26] Ideals of bravery and honour are repeatedly expressed in traditional Pashtun literature such as the Landay  which are exclusively composed and recited by women. One such popular verse reads:             “My beloved, if you turn your back upon the enemy, do not come home again! Go and seek refuge in a distant land.”[27]   According to the institution of badal, males are urged and expected to avenge their honour through heroic demonstrations of ‘masculinity’ pride, courage and bravery. Whether instigated through verbal ridicule, or the pitiless sentiments reverberating through Pashtun women’s poetry, it is perceived that women possess the power to humiliate men and pose a threat to male honour. Therefore, by generating considerable anxiety and fear, women could be perceived as the ‘conspirator’ and further as the catalyst, either directly or indirectly which forces men to bear the consequences of their own institutions and honour principles.      

[1] Lindholm, Charles. ‘Contemporary Politics in a Tribal Society,’ Asian Survey, University of California Press, (19:5), 1979, p.486.
[2] Lindholm, Charles, ‘The Structure of Violence among the Swat Pukhtun,’ Ethnology, University of Pittsburgh, (20:2), 1981, p.147.
[3] Britten, Arthur. Masculinity and Power, Basil Blackwell Ltd., 1989, p.16-17.
[4] Ibid., p.7.
[5] Foucault, Michel. Power/Knowledge: Selected Interviews and other writings, Colin Gordon (Ed.) The Harvester Press Ltd., 1980, p.107.
[6] Ibid., p.131.
[7] Foucault, Michel. Discipline and Punishment: The Birth of the Prison, Translated by: Alan Sheridan, Penguin Books, 1977, p.26.
[8] Bourdieu, Pierre. Masculine Domination, Translated by Richard Nice, Polity Press, 2007, p.9.
[9] Britten, Arthur. Masculinity and Power, Basil Blackwell Ltd., 1989, p.4.
[10] Barth, Fredrik. Political Leadership among Swat Pathans, Berg, 2004, p.133.
[11] Britten, Arthur. Masculinity and Power, Basil Blackwell Ltd., 1989, p.3.
[12] Barth, Fredrik. Ethnic Groups and Boundaries, George Allen & Unwin: London, 1970, p.122.
[13] Ibid., p.122.
[14] Glatzer, Bernt. ‘Being Pashtun – Being Muslim,’ Essays on South Asian Society, Das Arabische Buch, 1998, p.4.
[15] Report. ‘Afghanistan: Blood feuds, traditional law and conflict resolution,’ Landinfo, 2011, p.7.
[16] Barfield, Thomas. ‘Afghan Customary Law and Its Relationship to Formal Judicial Institutions,’ United States Institute for Peace: Washington DC, 2003, p.8.
[17] Ibid., p.4.
[18] Edwards, David B. Heroes of the Age: Moral Fault Lines on the Afghan Frontier, University of California Press, 1996, p.75.
[19] Ibid., p.76.
[20] Ibid., p.8.
[21] Nisbett, Richard E. & Cohen, Dov. ‘Insult, Aggression and the Southern Culture of Honor: An Experimental Ethnography,’ Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, (70:5), 1996, p.945.
[22] Ibid., p.945.
[23] Spierenburg, Pieter. Masculinity, Violence and Honour: An Introduction, The Ohio State University, 1998, p.2.
[24] Rzehak, Lutz. ‘Doing Pashto,’ Afghanistan Analysts Network: Thematic Report, 2011, p.15.
[25] Rzehak Lutz. ‘Doing Pashto: Pashtunwali as the ideal of honourable behaviour and tribal life among the Pashtuns,’ Afghanistan Analysts Network, Thematic Report, 2011, p.11.
[26] Majrouh, Sayd Bahodine. Songs of Love and War: Afghan Women’s Poetry, Translated by Jarjolijn De Jager, Other Press: New York, 2003, p.13.
[27] Ibid., p.16.

item.title: "Nothing to hope for"..........Suffering continues in Waziristan after operation Zarb-e-Azb
item.dc:creator: Mohsin Dawar
item.content:encoded:
After suffering both the brutal target killings by the Taliban and the Pakistan Army’s operations for over 10 years, the people of North Waziristan were ordered to leave their homeland overnight once orders for Operation Zarb-e-Azb were announced.
And they have been waiting for respite since the day they left. They fled Waziristan leaving behind their few precious belongings with only a pair of shoes and the clothes on their back. One million people left in a span of 24 hours without adequate transportation facilities. Except a few lucky ones, the rest had no option but to leave for Bannu on foot. They reached Bannu after a miserable journey that took anywhere between 24 to 60 hours (depending upon their location and conveyance) in the heat of June. Many people lost their lives due to thirst and hunger on the way.
During the turmoil of more than 10 years the people of North Waziristan have suffered in almost every aspect of their lives. The social structure, the jirga system which defines and disciplines their way of life, was demolished by replacing a Malik with a militant and the political administration with the military. The only job left for the political administration was to act as a messenger between the military and the militants using some newly manufactured vastly unpopular Maliks for that job. The real power play remained with the military and the militants.
Businesses were badly affected due to the uncertainty of being killed or kidnapped at any time by the Taliban, and because of the unexpected curfew imposed by the army at any time. Commercial property was highly devalued and curfews sometimes remained in force for weeks, which also affected the education of the students of North Waziristan.
Girls’ education all but disappeared and the only girls higher secondary school in Miranshah city was looted by the Taliban, its belongings sold off and the school building later used as a base office by the local Taliban. Due to the the influence and pressure of the militants the education system of Waziristan became a joke and even illiterates were passing BA and MA examinations with the help of proxies sitting in for them.
After going through all this and becoming IDPs in different areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa – mostly in Bannu – the people of Waziristan were once again treated badly by the state authorities. They were kept in hujras by local people but most of them resided in government schools which were vacant due to summer holidays. After the schools reopened, they were transferred to the Bakakhel camp and other areas. Due to neglect by the provincial and federal governments they suffered a lot in getting even basic facilities.
The IDPs waited for two to three months for their stipend and waited for hours in queues to get their monthly ration at the few ration collection areas set up for more than a million IDPs.
And after all this they were ready to forget all their miseries with a hope for a new Waziristan: A Waziristan that would be peaceful and free of militants. Where they would be free to run their businesses without paying any extortion money to the Taliban and where boys as well as girls would be able to be educated. Where there would be no militants nor would there be beheadings by the Taliban or mortar shelling by the army.
The IDPs believed that the state was never serious about taking out the militancy from the region and that it would continue to use it as part of the great strategic game in the region. But their hopes were still alive, and they felt that this time the operation would be effective as they saw the good Taliban getting weaker and the bad ones becoming stronger day by day. This was so especially after the tragic incident of December 16 when the political leadership of the country was on the same page to form a national action plan to tackle militancy.
These hopes were alive at the start of Operation Zarb-e-Azb and even after the consensus on the NAP but the people want something to be done in action. After seven to eight months of Operation Zarb-e-Azb the military has still to show a high-profile target killed or an arrest.
The recent talks between the military and the Haleem Khan group of the TTP in North Waziristan have also raised reservations that some may be spared.
The residents of Waziristan have been patient up to the very extreme extent. They have been through killings and humiliation at the hands of the Taliban and the army. They have left their homes and sacrificed as much as was possible for them. Now they want some positive results from the on-going military operation in North Waziristan. They want a militant-free Waziristan on return and anything other than that would be a great disappointment for them.
When all hope is lost and disappointment reaches extreme levels, the situation can lead towards an unidentified direction. The state should avoid creating such a situation especially when all the global powers in the region are operating as per their own vested interests.
The writer is a North Waziristan-based lawyer and political worker.
Email: mohsindawar@yahoo.com

item.title: The wretched of Waziristan
item.dc:creator: Mohsin Dawar
item.content:encoded:
It seems the traumatic times being faced by the voiceless people of North Waziristan are not coming to an end any time soon – in fact they may be getting worse. The irony is that the media does not seem bothered by whatever is happening to these people as almost all the activities related to them are handled by one institution.
Even the dreadful incident that took place recently at the Bakakhel IDP camp went unreported by the media. Urban generous Pakistan would rather raise funds and charity for the Rohingyas than talk of the miseries of their own internally displaced refugees. The question of accountability for the lives lost in Bakakhel cannot dare be entertained. If their dead bodies don’t count, their deplorable conditions would certainly not make anybody blink in urban Pakistan. Their dead are not considered worthy of even a small mention on our TV channels.
We are not aware of the rest of their miseries and what they have been through and the brutalities they have been dealt with. The IDPs are living in a wretched condition in the Bakakhel camp; the heat is unbearable and the tents used for more than a year are unable to stop its intensity of heat. Hats off to the only two international radio services, Dewa and Mashaal, who have given coverage to the grievances of the IDPs.
The ostrich-like reaction of our state and our people after the Bakakhel incident was a very clear message for the people of North Waziristan – your blood carries no value in this country. All the pillars of the state showed a criminal silence on the incident. There was no suo motu taken by the Supreme Court, no condemnation by parliament, no reports in the media but the most disappointing reaction was shown by the political parties who claim to be the representatives of the people. None of the political parties, except ANP, showed any grievance over the incident.
The post-operation situation does not sound so promising for these unfortunate people. It has been claimed that about 90 percent area has been cleared over the past year, but the question is why just 90 percent? There have not been any high-profile killings or arrests there. The real achievement of the operation would be to step into Shawal and some areas of Dattakhel – among the 10 percent area that is yet to be cleared.
There are also some reports and visual proofs that markets and buildings located in Miranshah and Mir Ali bazaars have been demolished. One of the videos shows that when you move onwards the agency headquarters hospital in Miranshah the markets and buildings are completely razed to ground. This is an area that used to be a very busy bustling place for business. Now it looks like a smooth playground and is hardly recognisable.
The owners of these shops and markets are still to hear any reasons over why their properties have been bulldozed. The problem is that they have no hope of justice. After watching these videos people are also worried about their homes and all the valuables they had left over there because they were only able to take some clothes along since they left in such a rush. Eyewitnesses are also reporting that there are some strange buildings under construction – over other people’s lands.
Along with all the hardships the IDPs are going through, their most popular demand was to let them go back home. Minister for SAFFRON Abdul Qadir Baloch and the officials of the Pakistan Army has been announcing different schedules for the IDPs’ return at different times but after watching photographs of demolished markets etc one wonders what they would do if they were sent back to their homes. Their markets have been bulldozed and no one knows the state of their homes. There are also reports of terrible mistreatment of those IDPs who have made it back home.
The people of North Waziristan were living with the hope that a time would come when they would be able to return to their homes and live normal lives. But after hearing about the agonies of those who went back and the hectic process of entering Waziristan, they are losing this only hope they had of a better life. This attitude of the state is creating anti-state sentiments amongst the IDPs and a spark from any quarter can lead towards disaster. The wretched are truly stuck between state and anti-state elements.
The writer is a North Waziristan-based lawyer and political worker.
Email: mohsindawar@yahoo.com

item.title: Supporting Pata
item.dc:creator: Mohsin Dawar
item.content:encoded:
Fata was the buffer zone during the colonial times against Russian communism. Currently it is the epicentre and theatre of terrorism. Ironically Fata, despite being the nucleus of the unrest in the country as well as being socially, economically and politically deprived, was badly ignored during the new social contract among different provinces in the shape of the 18th Amendment.

On the other hand, billions of dollars have been given to the Fata Secretariat by the international community in the name of bringing Fata into the mainstream by developing education, health and industrial infrastructure. But the area was badly ignored during the constitutional reforms – which were our version of the Magna Carta. After being ruled under the FCR for 68 years, Fata parliamentarians have finally decided to change the status of Fata. In a statement issued by them they have demanded that Fata be made a separate province or to merge it in Khyber Pukhtunkhwa. The statement went viral on social media. It was also unexpectedly signed by almost all Fata parliamentarians. The statement was followed by the properly drafted 22nd Amendment bill, which if approved will change the status of Fata (Federally Administrated Tribal Areas) into Pata (Provincially Administrated Tribal Areas). The bill seeks amendments in articles 1, 246 and 247 of the constitution of Islamic republic of Pakistan. The bill demands to remove the term Fata from the constitution by omitting Article 1 sub article 2 clause C of the constitution. The bill also demands an amendment in Article 246 by adding the six FRs and seven tribal agencies to Pata in clause b and by omitting clause c of the aforesaid article. Among the other amendments demanded in the controversial Article 247 of the constitution, the most important one is Section 5 of the article which extends the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and high courts to the tribal areas. The abrupt move to mainstream Fata has started a new debate regarding the bill. Irrespective of the merits and demerits of the bill, some intellectuals have seen it as a suspicious move and have been trying to find some conspiracy in this unexpected action taken by Fata parliamentarians. Some political analysts have come with a counter to this bill; they reject the proposed amendments and demand absolute and complete mainstreaming of Fata. Some of the status-quo symbols from Fata who had always been the beneficiaries of the FCR and political administration have also jumped into the debate, and against the bill. They have started campaigning to oppose the bill with as much intensity as possible, because the bill affects their interests. The bill has been submitted in the National Assembly and a heated debate is expected on it. Though some of the critics of the bill are of the view that it will not address the agonies of the people of Fata, I believe the bill is significant for the people of Fata. The extension of the jurisdictions of the Supreme Court and high courts will be a great achievement for the people of Fata. It will place a limit on the unlimited powers of the governor and the president as any order violating basic human rights will be subject to judicial review, and the higher judiciary can strike down any order violating basic human rights. There is also an argument that a political agent will be replaced by a deputy commissioner in case of Pata but I believe that the situation will be extremely different. In Fata the system is run by unaccountable political agents while in Pata the DC will be the subordinate of the provincial government. The representatives of all the constituencies of Pata will be a part of the provincial setup. Whether they sit in the opposition or are a part of the government, the bureaucracy will be under the provincial government. In Pata the executive is always reluctant to take any action that results in creating a nuisance for the provincial government while the political agent in Fata has no such considerations. With the proposed amendment the people of Fata might also get rid of the unethical and unpopular decisions of the Ministry of SAFRON which has recently categorised the Maliks of Fata. The parameters set to categorise the Maliks is that the more one has served as a facilitator between the militants and the political administration the higher will be the category awarded to him. Genuine leadership or elders who were threatened and forced to quit the area at the start of militancy in the area will be given lowest lower category according to this criteria. The proposal is under consideration and, if implemented, will create more confusion and disappointment as people ranked on the top are unpopular if they have no mass backing. To get rid of all these decisions made by different segments of the state, the people of Fata should strongly come forward to support this bill. The step taken by Fata parliamentarians to break the status quo is highly appreciable. Irrespective of what the track record of the Fata parliamentarians has been, we should support them if they are doing something better. The current bill is also a test case for all the political parties of Pakistan who are always claiming to be the leading advocates for Fata’s rights. It is now time to prove that practically, respect the mandate of Fata parliamentarians and vote in favour of the bill. There is no doubt that the proposed amendment will not bring about complete and absolute mainstreaming of Fata. But instead of demanding something which might not be easily attainable, we shouldn’t lose the opportunity of getting something we are on track to achieve. Let us support the bill and take the first step of getting out of the years-old regime of political agents. The writer is a North Waziristan-based lawyer and political worker.
